questions.text: A 28-year-old HIV patient presents with non-productive cough and difficulty in breathing which was progressively increasing. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates along with pneumatocele. Gomori’s methenamine silver staining of the bronchoalveolar lavage shows the following. The most probable causative organism is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the GMS stain showing the black colored stained cysts resembling the crushed ping pong balls are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia. It is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive.

Pneumocystis jirovecii causes pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in AIDS patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/mm3 and usually presents with fever, dry cough, and dyspnea. Inspiratory crackles are heard on auscultation.

The most common finding on chest x-ray if the disease is suspected early is either a normal film or a faint bilateral interstitial infiltrate. The classic finding of a dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

The chest radiograph given below shows ground-glass opacities in PCP.

Treatment: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and pentamidine isethionate.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. She gives a similar history of hearing loss to her mother.  The otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes are given below. The pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curves bilaterally. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is active otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normal dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It has a positive family history with an autosomal dominant trait. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy. It may be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta and a viral infection like measles. 

Patients present with a bilateral conductive type of hearing loss, tinnitus (commonly in cochlear type and active stage), paracusis Willisii (better hearing in a noisy surroundings than in a quiet place), vertigo, and a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech. The otoscopic picture shows a reddish hue on the promontory through the tympanic membrane, called the Schwartze sign. This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity.

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile. Eustachian tube function is also normal. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure.

Treatment includes medical, surgical management, and hearing aids. Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage to hasten the maturity of the active focus and halt further cochlear loss. The treatment of choice is surgical, that includes stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

Audiogram given below shows Cahart's notch seen in otosclerosis.

Other options:

Option A: Repeated exposure to loud sounds above 85 dB or single exposure to loud sounds above 120-155 dB such as explosions, gunshots etc, can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. It results in bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz.

Option C: Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear that arises from the glomus bodies. When the tumor is intratympanic, the hearing loss is a conductive type and a swishing, pulsatile tinnitus that is synchronous with the carotid pulse is heard. On otoscopic examination, a red reflex through the tympanic membrane is seen. This is known as the 'rising sun' appearance.

Option D: Meniere's disease (endolymphatic hydrops) is an inner ear disorder where the endolymph distends the endolymphatic system. It is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sense of ear fullness.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

Related Pearl: Meniere’s disease vs. Otosclerosis

Meniere’s Disease

Otosclerosis

Middle age (M>F)

Middle age (F>>M)

Unilateral

Bilateral

Sensory neural hearing loss

Conductive Hearing loss

Cochlear pathology (endolymphatic system)

Middle ear pathology (stapes footplate)

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for ear pain after a tonsillectomy surgery ?
questions.solution:
The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referred otalgia after a tonsillectomy.

The tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve. The glossopharyngeal nerve and the styloid process lie in relation to the lower part of the tonsillar fossa. Therefore, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

Image below shows the anatomic relations of tonsil and tonsillar bed.

The ear receives an extensive sensory innervation via four cranial nerves (V, VII, IX, and X) and two spinal segments (C2 and C3).

Jacobson's nerve along with branches from the sympathetic plexus forms the tympanic plexus. This plexus provides sensation to the middle ear, upper eustachian tube, and medial surface of the tympanic membrane. Referred otalgia transmitted by the glossopharyngeal nerve may be secondary to lesions and/or inflammatory processes of the nasopharynx, palatine tonsil, soft palate, or posterior one-third of the tongue.

Causes of referred otalgia via glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Acute pharyngitis
  • Tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess
  • Post-tonsillectomy
  • Foreign bodies embedded in the base of the tongue or tonsillar area
  • Elongated styloid process

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is on treatment develops a HBA1c level of 8.1%. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
A hypertensive patient developing diabetes should be switched to telmisartan.

Telmisartan, an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), has shown evidence of having PPAR-gamma agonist action. It is very useful in hypertensive patients with diabetes. PPAR-gamma agonists are the thiazolidinedione group of drugs that act by inducing several insulins sensitizing genes, thereby reducing overall insulin resistance.

ACE inhibitors or ARBs are the first-line treatment of choice for hypertension in a diabetic patient. They reduce proteinuria and delay diabetic nephropathy, a benefit that is not seen with beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.

questions.text: An infant had serum bilirubin levels at 33 mg/dL. Which drug may the mother have taken during the third trimester for this to occur?
questions.solution:
Cotrimoxazole is a combination drug consisting of trimethoprim and sulphamethoxazole of which sulphamethoxazole is a sulfonamide. Sulfonamide is thought to displace bilirubin which is bound to albumin and reduce bilirubin binding capacity in plasma leading to an elevation of plasma bilirubin.

The blood-brain barrier is more permeable in newborns especially in premature babies, and displacement of bilirubin from plasma albumin binding sites by sulfonamides can precipitate kernicterus.

questions.text: The following sign is seen in a patient presenting with rhinorrhea following a skull base fracture. Identify the sign.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Double target sign or Halo sign or Target sign seen in CSF rhinorrhoea and suggests basal skull fracture due to trauma in this case.

Double target sign is seen patients with CSF rhinorrhea. The nasal discharge in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea after head trauma is mixed with blood. When this discharge is collected on a filter paper, it shows a double target sign with a central red spot and a peripheral lighter halo. 

The following features help in differentiating CSF rhinorrhoea from nasal secretions:  

Features CSF Fluid Nasal Secretions

History

Nasal or sinus surgery, head injury, or intracranial tumor

Sneezing, nasal stuffiness, itching in the nose, or lacrimation

Flow of discharge

A few drops or a stream of fluid gushes down with bending forward or straining

cannot be sniffed back

Continuous and no effect with bending forward or straining.

Can be sniffed back

Character of discharge

Thin, watery, and clear

Slimy (mucus) or clear (tears)

Taste

Sweet

Salty

Sugar content

More than 30 mg/dL

Less than 10 mg/dl

Presence of β2 transferrin

Always present

 Always absent

Note: Nasal discharge stiffens the handkerchief because of the presence of mucus.

A basilar skull fracture occurs due to direct impact behind the ear or crush injuries of the head and present with the following features:

  • Hemotympanum
  • Battle sign: bruising behind the ear
  • Racoon eyes
  • CSF rhinorrhoea

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double target sign or Halo sign or Target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.
  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

Note: Reservoir sign is also seen in acute mastoiditis/ coalescent mastoiditis where mastoid acts as a reservoir of pus and pus reappear in EAC immediately after cleaning.

questions.text: What is the sodium content in oral rehydration solution as per WHO?
questions.solution:
The sodium content in WHO ORS is 75 mmol/L. 

Oral rehydration solution (ORS): It is a solution designed to replace fluids and electrolytes in patients with diarrhoea. The 1:1 molar ratio of glucose and sodium in the WHO ORS is based on the principle of glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption in the gut.

Component (Mmol/L) Standard ORS ReSoMal
Glucose 75 (anhydrous) 125
Sodium 75 45
Potassium 20 40
Chloride 65 76
Osmolarity (mosm/L) 245 300

ReSoMal is oral rehydration salt or ORS for severely malnourished children. It is used in in-patient centres for the treatment of children with severe acute malnutrition. ReSoMal contains more glucose (125 mmol/L) and a lower amount of sodium (45 mmol/L) than the standard WHO-ORS. Other homemade fluids containing salt are also recommended to improve hydration in children.

Drinks sweetened with sugar, carbonated beverages, commercial fruit juices, and sweetened tea cause osmotic diarrhea and hypernatremia and are dangerous in patients with diarrhoea. Fluids with stimulant diuretic or purgative effects such as coffee, medicinal tea with infusions, etc. should also be avoided.

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

Composition Low-osmolar ORS (mmol/L) ReSoMal (mmol/L)
Glucose  75 125
Sodium  75  45
Potassium  20  40
Chloride  65  70
Citrate  10  7
Magnesium  ---  3
Zinc  --- 0.3
Copper  --- 0.045
Osmolarity (mOsmol/L) 245 300

questions.text: Identify the labelled structure
questions.solution:
The labelled structure is the Internal capsule.

The internal capsule is a component of the white matter of the brain. They contain projection fibers. It can be divided into the following parts:

  • anterior limb
  • genu
  • posterior limb
  • retrolenticular/ retrolentiform portion
  • sublenticular/ sublentiform portion

The anterior limb of the internal capsule carries the fronto-pontine fibers, while the genu carries the corticonuclear tract. 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule carries cortico-spinal motor fibers in the anterior part. The posterior part of the posterior limb of the internal capsule carries sensory fibers.

The retrolenticular part contains the parietopontine, occipitopontine and occipitotectal fibres and the sublenticular part contains temporopontine and some parietopontine fibres.

The basal ganglia constitutes accessory motor system that functions in close association with the cerebral cortex and corticospinal motor control system. On each side of the brain, these ganglia consist of the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen+ globus pallidus
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen 

The internal capsule separates the thalamus and the caudate nucleus from the lentiform nucleus. The caudate nucleus is a C-shaped mass of grey matter. It is divided into a head, body, and tail. Degeneration of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington's disease. 

Both the Putamen and external capsule lie lateral to globus pallidus. It receives fibers from the striatum and subthalamic nuclei. It acts as the main output of the basal ganglia to the thalamus and superior colliculus. The substantia nigra is seen in each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri. The levels of dopamine in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in parkinsonism disease.

Related Pearl: Connections and Neurotransmitters in Basal Ganglia

  Input Output Neurotransmitter
Corpus Striatum Cerebral cortex and Thalamus GPe and GPi

95% GABA (small neurons)

5% Ach (large neurons) / Somatostatin (Medium neurons)
GPe Striatum GPi and Subthalamic nucleus GABA 
GPi and Substantia nigra pars reticulate (SNpR) Striatum and GPe Ventrolateral and ventroanterior Thalamus GABA
Subthalamic nucleus GPe GPi and GPe Glutamate
Substantia Nigra pars compacta (SNpC) Striatum Stritum Dopamine
Ventrolateral Thalamus GPi and SNpR Premotor Cortex Glutamate

Alcohol substitution therapy is not a service offered through targeted interventions for the high-risk group under NACO guidelines. 

The following are the main services offered through targeted interventions:

  • Detection and treatment of sexually transmitted infections
  • Condom distribution 
  • Condom promotion through social marketing 
  • Behavioral change communication

  • Linkages to integrated counseling and testing centers
  • Linkages with care and support services for HIV-positive high-risk groups.
  • Community organization and ownership building.
  • Specific interventions for injecting drug users

questions.text: A child had recurrent bouts of infections. The diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease was made using the nitroblue tetrazolium test. This test assesses the functions of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The nitroblue tetrazolium test assesses the function of polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMN).

Nitroblue tetrazolium assay is used as a diagnostic test, particularly for chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). It tests the reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in neutrophils and monocytes.

Chronic granulomatous disease is a rare X-linked recessive disease. It is characterized by the impaired phagocytic killing of microorganisms by neutrophils and macrophages. Defects in NADPH oxidase lead to defective production of reactive oxygen species after phagocytosis.

These patients have frequent infections by catalase-positive organisms such as S. aureus, Burkholderia cepacia complex, Nocardia, Aspergillus, etc. Recurrent folliculitis may prompt early diagnosis of the condition. Following these infections, there is extensive inflammation and suppuration despite antibiotic therapy.

Other features include aphthous ulcers, inflammation of the nares, and granulomas. Granulomas can cause obstruction of the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tracts. Autoimmune complications like immune thrombocytopenic purpura and juvenile idiopathic arthritis may also occur.

Management of CGD is mainly treating infections with antibiotics or antifungals depending on the cause. Granulomas are sensitive to steroids and glucocorticoids can be given. 

Other options:

Options B and C: B and T lymphocytes can be assessed by lymphocyte phenotyping. It is useful in the diagnosis of T-cell immunodeficiencies and agammaglobulinemia.

Option D: Complements can be assessed by CH50 and AP50, which are useful in diagnosing complement deficiencies.

questions.text: The image shows cardiac action potential graphs. At the point indicated by ‘A’,
questions.solution:
At the beginning of plateau phase, Slow Calcium channels open.

Phases of cardiac action potential

  • 0→ Depolarisation and overshoot
    • Due to opening of voltage-gated Na+channels
  • 1→ Initial rapid repolarization
    • Due to closure of Na+channels and opening up of K+channels
  • 2→ Plateau phase
    • Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+channels
  • 3→ Late rapid repolarization
  • 4→ Baseline (RMP)
    • Phases 3 and 4 are due closure of Ca2+ channels and a slow, delayed increase of K+efflux through K+ channels.
  • Until about half of phase 3 of cardiac action potential, cardiac muscle cannot be excited again, that is, it is in its absolute refractory period. It remains relatively refractory until phase 4. Thus, cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized.

questions.text: Neonatal line is an indication of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Neonatal line is an incremental line found on the surface of tooth enamel that indicates that an infant was live born.

  • The study of dental microstructure, which involves counting perikymata (incremental lines on the surface of tooth enamel), can provide an accurate method of age determination.
  • One particularly pronounced incremental line, the neonatal line, can be of medicolegal significance in determining whether an infant was live-born or stillborn.
  • It is formed very soon after birth and can be visualized by light microscopy if the child survived for about 3 weeks or by electron microscopy within 1 or 2 days of birth.

questions.text: All are true about Hashimoto’s thyroiditis except______.
questions.solution:
All the above features are seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis except orphan annie eye nuclei. Orphan Annie eye nuclei are seen in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Hashimoto thyroiditis

  • An autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual and progressive thyroid failure.
  • Presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase
  • Most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas of the world where iodine levels are sufficient
  • Female predominance
  • Thyroid often diffusely enlarged, painless, with some degree of hypothyroidism
  • May be preceded by transient thyrotoxicosis (“hashitoxicosis”).
  • Extensive infiltration of the parenchyma by small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centres
  • The thyroid follicles are atrophic and are lined in many areas by Hürthle cells.
  • Increased risk of developing other autoimmune diseases.
  • Increased risk for the development of extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphomas and papillary carcinoma within the thyroid gland.

questions.text: What percentage of drug given will be left in the body after 3 half-lives, If the drug is eliminated by first order kinetics?
questions.solution:
The percentage of drug given will be left in the body if the drug eliminates by first-order kinetics after 3 half-lives is 12.5%.

In first-order kinetics, the rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional to the drug concentration.

The rate of clearance remains constant.

Half-life Elimination (%) Drug left in the body(%)
First 50  50
Second 75  25
Third 87.5  12.5
Fourth 93.75  6.25

Related Pearl: First order Vs Zero order kinetics of drugs

First order

Zero order

Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

Clearance remains constant

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

Half-life remains constant

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

questions.text: On centrifugation of a cell, LDH will get deposited in __?
questions.solution:
On centrifugation of a cell , the cell organelles can be seperated and then detected by specific marker enzymes. LDH is a marker enzyme of cytoplasm and hence will get deposited in the cytoplasm itself.

Other options:

Mitochondria are organelles responsible for cellular respiration and energy production. They contain enzymes involved in the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle) and the electron transport chain. LDH is primarily found in the cytoplasm, not within mitochondria. While some LDH isoforms have been reported in the mitochondria of certain cell types, the bulk of LDH activity is in the cytoplasm.

Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles containing various hydrolytic enzymes involved in cellular digestion and waste processing. LDH is not typically found in lysosomes. 

The Golgi complex (or Golgi apparatus) is involved in modifying, sorting, and packaging proteins and lipids for transportation within the cell or secretion outside the cell. LDH is not a protein processed or stored within the Golgi complex. Its primary site of action is in the cytoplasm, where it catalyzes biochemical reactions involved in energy metabolism.

Cell Organelles Marker enzyme
Mitochondria ATP synthase (inner membrane)
Lysosome Cathepsin
Golgi Complex Galactosyl transferase
Microsome Glucose-6-Phosphatase
Cytoplasm Lactate dehydrogenase

 

Related Pearl: Cell Organelles and Enzyme Markers

Enzyme Markers

Histone deacetylase

ATP synthase, glutamate dehydrogenase, creatine kinase

Endoplasmic reticulum

Glucose-6-Phosphatase

apparatus

questions.text: Which of these is an oncofetal antigen?
questions.solution:
An oncofetal antigen is a protein that is typically expressed at high levels during fetal development but is re-expressed in certain cancers. Both α-fetoprotein (AFP) and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) are examples of oncofetal antigens.

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

  • Valuable clinical aid in diagnosis, prognosis and monitoring primary hepatocellular carcinoma, hepatoblastoma, non-seminomatous testicular germ cell tumors, embryonal carcinoma, teratomas, choriocarcinoma, yolk sac carcinoma, germ cell tumors of the ovary and extragonadal germ cell tumors
  • Hepatoblastoma: an embryonic form has always been found to be associated with grossly elevated serum AFP levels.
  • Regenerated hepatic tissue following liver damage due to viral hepatitis, chemically induced necrosis, and liver surgery are associated with moderately raised serum AFP levels.

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)

  • Normally detected in glycocalyx of fetal epithelial cells
  • May play a role in the metastasis of cancer cells
  • CEA levels over 5 ng/dL: ascites fluid A/W malignancy
  • Detection, recurrence, and prognosis of adenocarcinoma (lung) and colorectal carcinoma
  • Elevated levels also present in cirrhosis, biliary obstruction, hepatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, smokers and post-surgical bowel sequestration with mucocele
  • Benign cysts may be CEA+ even when benign
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma: canalicular pattern for polyclonal CEA is 50-90% sensitive for hepatocellular carcinoma, > 95% specific
  • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma: 92% sensitive for metastases vs. 0% for bile duct adenoma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the ophthalmologist with complaints of diminished vision in the right eye for the past few months. He says that he had undergone cataract surgery 5 years back. on examination, the following finding is noted in the eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of a white ring behind the iris. The likely diagnosis is Soemmering’s ring.

Soemmering’s ring is a type of secondary or after-cataract. It is the opacity that persists or develops after the extracapsular lens extraction. If the posterior capsule is clear and doesn't interfere with the vision, then it requires no treatment. Thin membranous cataracts are treated with YAG-laser
capsulotomy or discission with cystitome or Zeigler’s knife. Dense after cataract requires surgical membranectomy.

Important complications of cataract surgery

  • Operative complications
    • Superior rectus muscle laceration while applying a briddle suture.
    • Excessive bleeding
    • Button holing the anterior wall
    • Scleral disinsertion. It occurs due to a deeper incision. The superior sclera separates from the inferior sclera at the line of incision.
    • Injury to the cornea and the iris
    • Rupture of the posterior capsule
    • Loss of vitreous humor
    • Nucleus drop into the vitreous cavity
    • Expulsive choroidal hemorrhage. It is a dreaded complication that commonly occurs in hypertensive. There is an expulsion of lens, vitreous, retina, uvea, and blood.
  • Early postoperative complications
    • Hyphaema-Collection of blood in the anterior chamber. It occurs due to an injury to the conjunctival or scleral vessels. 
    • Iris prolapse- is caused due to the inadequate suturing of the incision.
    • Striate keratopathy is characterised by mild corneal edema with Descemet’s folds. It occurs due to the injury of the endothelial cells during the surgery
    • Shallow anterior chamber- can occur as a result of wound leak, ciliochoroidal detachment, or pupillary block.
    • Postoperative anterior uveitis
    • Toxic anterior segment syndrome
    • Bacterial endophthalmitis
  • Late postoperative complications
    • Cystoid macular edema- is the collection of fluid in the Henle's layer of the macula. In most cases, it is clinically insignificant and undergoes spontaneous regression.
    • Delayed chronic postoperative endophthalmitis- is caused when organisms of low virulence like propionibacterium acne or staph epidermidis get trapped in the capsular bag. It is seen around 9 months after the surgery.
    • Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy- is the corneal edema occurring due to the injury to the endothelium.
    • Retinal detachment
    • Epithelial ingrowth- infiltration of the epithelial cells into the anterior chamber
    • Fibrous downgrowth
    • After cataract- 
      • Soemmering’s ring refers to a thick ring of after cataract formed behind the iris, enclosed between the two layers of the capsule
      • Elschnig’s pearls referees to the accumulation of the vacuolated epithelial cells clustered like soap bubbles along with the posterior capsule.
    • Intraocular lens-related (IOL) complications- cystoid macular edema, corneal damage, glaucoma, etc. and malpositions of the IOL
      • Sunset syndrome- inferior subluxation of IOL
      • Sunrise syndrome- superior subluxation of IOL
      • Lost lens syndrome refers to the complete dislocation of an IOL into the vitreous cavity.
      • Windshield wider syndrome- It results when a very small IOL is placed vertically in the capsule. In this, the superior loop moves to the left and right, with movements of the head.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: Oval cells are seen in _____.
questions.solution:
Oval cells are seen in the liver. These are stem cells located in the canals of Hering.

Regeneration of the liver occurs by two major mechanisms:

1. Proliferation of hepatocytes- In humans, resection of up to 90% of the liver can be corrected by proliferation of the residual hepatocytes.

2. Liver regeneration from progenitor cells- In situations where the proliferative capacity of hepatocytes is impaired, such as after chronic liver injury or inflammation, progenitor cells(oval cells) in the liver contribute to repopulation.

questions.text: Pott’s puffy tumor is
questions.solution:
Pott's puffy tumor is the subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone.

It is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is not developed in infants and children.

Osteomyelitis of the frontal bone results from acute infection of frontal sinus either directly or through the venous spread. It can also follow trauma or surgery of the frontal sinus in the presence of acute infection. Pus may form externally under the periosteum as soft doughy swelling (Pott’s puffy tumour), or internally as an extradural abscess.

Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, drainage of abscess and trephining of frontal sinus through its floor. Sometimes, it requires removal of sequestra and necrotic bone by raising a scalp flap through a coronal incision.

questions.text: Lesions in which nucleus of the hypothalamus produce a voracious appetite and rage?

choices.text: Upper region of the lateral hypothalamus

questions.solution:
A lesion in the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus, the satiety center, is responsible for producing a voracious appetite and rage.

Lesions in the upper region of the lateral hypothalamus produce a profound loss of appetite.

questions.text: After a meal, the plasma levels of insulin has peaked in a person. Which of the following glucose transporters would facilitate the uptake of glucose by the skeletal muscles mediated by insulin?
questions.solution:
The glucose transporter that would facilitate the uptake of glucose by the skeletal muscles mediated by insulin is GLUT-4.

Normally, a pool of GLUT-4 molecules is maintained within vesicles in the cytoplasm of the insulin-sensitive cells. When the insulin receptors in them are stimulated, the vesicles move rapidly and fuse themselves to the cell membrane and facilitate the transport of glucose molecules into the cells.

This GLUT-4 receptor is also present in cardiac muscle and adispose tissues.

questions.text: A middle-aged man comes with complaints of sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm and profuse sweating. An ECG taken showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Which of the following is true regarding blood lactate dehydrogenase levels in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden onset chest pain with profuse sweating and ECG with ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is suggestive of myocardial Infarction. Serum LDH 1 > LDH 2 levels are seen in this condition. 

Under normal conditions, LDH 2 is predominantly present in the blood and LDH 1 is predominantly present in the heart. So, normally LDH 2 > LDH 1 in blood. When cardiac tissue is damaged LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream. This results in a flipped lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) ratio where LDH 1 > LDH 2.

LDH is a tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (heart) and M isoform (muscle)

LDH-2 HHHM Heart and RBC
LDH-3 HHMM Lungs, brain, lymphatic tissues, and platelets
LDH-4 HMMM Liver and skeletal muscle
LDH-5 MMMM Liver and skeletal muscle

questions.text: Safety pin appearance is seen in________
questions.solution:
Safety pin appearance is seen in Burkholderia pseudomallei.

Burkholderia pseudomallei (Whitmore bacillus):

  • Causative agent for malleidosis (pyogenic or granulomatous infection)
  • Motile
  • Microscopy: Small irregular staining gram negative bacilli showing typical bipolar safety pin appearance with methylene blue stain
  • DOC: Ceftazidime

Organisms which show a bipolar or safety pin appearance on microscopy include

  • Burkholderia pseudomallei
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Yersinia enterocolitica
  • Pasteurella multocida
  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Vibrio parahemolyticus
  • Calymmatobacterium granulomatis/ Klebsiella granulomatis

questions.text:
Match the following with their rate-limiting enzymes:
1- Heme synthesis a- HMG CoA reductase
2- Cholesterol synthesis b- Phosphofructokinase
3- Glycolysis c- ALA synthase
4- Niacin synthesis d- HMG CoA synthase
  e- Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-e.

Heme synthesis ALA synthase
Cholesterol synthesis HMG CoA reductase
Glycolysis Phosphofructokinase
Niacin syntheses Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase

Heme is synthesized in the normoblasts except matures erythrocytes. Heme synthesis is partly mitochondrial and partly cytoplasmic. It starts with the condensation of succinyl CoA and glycine by ALA synthase in the presence of pyridoxal phosphate to form delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA). ALA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme and is located in mitochondria. 

All nucleated cells including the arterial wall can synthesize cholesterol and the liver, adrenal cortex, testis, ovaries, and intestines are the major sites of cholesterol synthesis. It occurs partly in the endoplasmic reticulum and cytoplasm. it starts with the condensation of two molecules of acetyl CoA to form acetoacetyl CoA synthase. 

The reduction of HMG CoA to mevalonate catalyzed by HMG CoA reductase is the rate-limiting step. it is the rate-limiting enzyme and is located in the endoplasmic reticulum. 

Statin group of drugs like lovastatin are competitive inhibitors of HMG CoA reductase and can be used in clinical practice to reduce cholesterol levels in the blood. 

Glycolysis converts glucose to pyruvate (aerobic condition) or lactate (anaerobic condition) with the production of a small quantity of energy. It takes place in all cells of the body. Phosphofructokinase is the rate-limiting enzyme that converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1-6-bisphosphate.

The rate-limiting enzyme of synthesis of niacin from tryptophan is quinolinate phosphoribosyltransferase. It converts niacin or nicotinic acid to nicotinate mononucelotide.

questions.text: Identify the yoke muscle for the muscle marked below?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the above image is left superior oblique, hence the corresponding yoke muscle will be right inferior rectus. (Its left eye because of the presence of medial septum to the right to eyeball) 

Yoke muscles are contralateral synergists. They are a pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contracts simultaneously during version movements.

Examples are:

  • Right MR and Left LR
  • Right IO and Left SR

questions.text: Which is the study design of choice to identify the prevalence of a disease?
questions.solution:
Cross-sectional study is done to identify the prevalence of a disease.

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

 

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Other options:
Option B: An ambispective cohort is the combination of both retrospective and prospective cohort studies.
Option C: In a case-control study, the study begins from the outcome and goes retrospectively to find out the exposure among the cases and controls.
Option D: In case of a prospective cohort study, the study population is followed up regularly to look for the effects of exposure. 

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

Incidence in Epidemiology:

  • Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time.
  • Incidence = (Number of cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time) x 1000
  • Incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year.
  • It provides insight into the effectives of health services and programs.
  • Incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000
  • It is generally used for acute illnesses.
  • Special types of incidence rates:
    • Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.
    • Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.
  • Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Prevalence in Epidemiology:

  • Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.
  • It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio.
  • It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.
  • Types:
    • Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.
    • Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.
  • Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.
  • Prevalence = (Number of all cases of a specified disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at the same point in time) x 100
  • It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

  • Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.
  • Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration
  • Longer the duration of the disease, greater the prevalence.
  • In acute diseases,because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence.This is because in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as duration of disease decreases.
  • If treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A new family is a nuclear family that is younger than how many years?
questions.solution:
• The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
  • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.

Related Pearl: The Family as a Social Organization

  • A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.
  • It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.
  • The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

 

Phase

Beginning

End

1

Formation

Marriage

Birth of 1st child

2

Extension

Birth of 1st child

Birth of last child

3

Complete extension

Birth of last child

1st child leaves home

4

Contraction

1st child leaves home

Last child leaves parental home

5

Completed contraction

Last child leaves parental home

Death of 1st spouse

6

Dissolution

Death of 1st spouse

Death of survivor
  • Types of families:
    • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
    • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
    • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
    • A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
    • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.
  • Functions of the family:
    • Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)
    • Division of labour
    • Reproduction and raising children
    • Socialization and social care
    • Economic functions
  • Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.
  • Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases aldosterone secretion?
questions.solution:
Hypernatremia decreases aldosterone secretion. 

The following factors are known to play roles in the regulation of aldosterone: 

  • Hyperkalemia increases aldosterone
  • Increased angiotensin II concentration increases aldosterone secretion.
  • Hypernatermia concentration in the extracellular fluid very slightly decreases aldosterone secretion.
  • ACTH from the anterior pituitary gland is necessary for aldosterone secretion but has minimal effect in physiological conditions.

questions.text: A  public witness of the incident is asked to attend the court and record his evidence. Which type of evidence is provided by the witness to the court?
questions.solution:
The evidence provided by a public witness of the incident to the court is oral evidence.

Oral evidence is given by a person who has personal knowledge of the facts associated with a particular incident. It is the evidence given by an eyewitness. The oral evidence should be direct whenever possible according to Section 55 BSA (Section 60 Indian Evidence Act). It includes all the statements made by the witness in relation to the inquiry which is permitted by the court. 

Other options: 

Option B: Hearsay evidence is a type of evidence given by a person who has no personal knowledge of the facts in relation to the incident but only repeats what he heard others saying. 

Option C: Subpnea is also known as summons. It is an authoritative call to appear in court. It is a document compelling the attendance of a witness in a Court of law under penalty, on a particular day, time, and place, for the purpose of giving evidence. It is issued by the Court. Sections 63 to 71 of BNSS deal with the summons. 

Option D: Circumstantial evidence is also known as indirect evidence. It is not the direct testimony of an eye witness but has a bearing upon the fact of the other and subsidiary facts which are relied upon as consistent. This type of evidence needs the Court of Law to make reasonable inferences based on the information presented.

Related Pearl: Doctor and The Court

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought with loud, raspy, and noisy breathing. His mother also says that his voice has become hoarse over the past 3-4 months. He was born at term through an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The fiberoptic laryngoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of laryngeal papilloma or recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.

It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is caused by human papilloma DNA virus (HPV) types 6 and 11. Squamous papillomas can be seen in children, juvenile papillomatosis (as in this case), and in adults, adult-onset papilloma. 

It is thought that the patients acquire this condition from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus infection during birth. It is usually seen in the supraglottic and glottic regions. Less commonly, the subglottis, trachea, and bronchi may be involved.

Clinically, the patient is typically a young child 3-5 years of age. They may present with hoarseness of voice, stridor, and breathing difficulty. The disease recurs requiring repeated surgical and medical management throughout childhood. Rarely, they may undergo malignant change. 

It is diagnosed using flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and may later be confirmed by direct laryngoscopy or rigid bronchoscopy and biopsy.

Treatment of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis:

  • Surgical management with excision using a CO2 laser
  • Medical management using interferon-alpha has been tried as an adjuvant, but it is associated with significant side effects 

The adult-onset version is usually less severe and does not recur after surgical removal. It affects males more than females and presents between the ages of 30-50 years. 

Other options: 

Option A - Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition of the larynx that manifests at birth and disappears by the age of 2 years. Babies present with stridor on crying that relieves in the prone position. 

The following image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis of laryngomalacia:

 

Option B - Reinke's edema is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. 

The following image shows Reinke's edema:

 

Option C - Vocal cord nodules occur at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cords. This occurs due to vocal trauma that happens when the patient speaks in low tones or high intensities for prolonged periods. 

The following image shows a unilateral vocal nodule:

questions.text:
A patient comes with complaints of frequent changes in her presbyopic glasses. On gonioscopy, the anterior chamber angle appears normal. Perimetry shows a small wing-shaped paracentral scotoma. IOP is measured to be 23mmHg. What is the likely diagnosis?

IOP - Intraocular pressure
questions.solution:
A history of frequent changes of presbyopic glasses with an increased IOP and paracentral scotoma suggests a likely diagnosis of primary open-angle glaucoma.

Primary open-angle glaucoma/chronic simple glaucoma occurs due to reduced aqueous outflow facility which is caused by trabecular meshwork stiffening. It is characterized by open anterior chamber angle, characteristic optic disc cupping, specific visual field defects, and a slowly progressive increase of IOP.  

Symptoms such as new-onset headache/eye ache are present. However, patients most commonly present with frequent changes in presbyopic glasses.

The optic disc changes are progressive with an increasing cup: disc (C/D) ratio (normal is 0.3 to 0.4), nasal shifting of retinal vessels (Bayonetting sign), and finally resulting in glaucomatous optic atrophy where the optic disc appears excavated. Visual field defects, such as small wing-shaped paracentral scotoma, is the earliest clinically significant scotoma. 

Tonometry and central corneal thickness measurement should be done to correctly measure IOP. Normal IOP ranges from 11- 21mmHg. To rule out other glaucomas gonioscopy is done. Visual field defects are detected by perimetry.

Medical therapy such as prostaglandin analogs, topical beta-blockers, etc are used in treatment. Laser trabeculoplasty and trabeculotomy can be required if it is not managed medically.

Other options:

Option A: Primary angle-closure glaucoma occurs due to slow synechiae closure of the anterior chamber angle. Otherwise, other presentations are similar to open-angle glaucoma with optic disc cupping and visual field defects. 

Option C: Ocular hypertension is defined as a persistent increase of IOP without optic disc changes and visual field defects. 

Option D: Normal-tension glaucoma occurs when the IOP is normal and below 21mmHg, but there is typical glaucomatous change and visual field defects.

Below attached pearl shows the various field defects of glaucoma.

questions.text: The maneuver depicted in below given diagram is ________
questions.solution:
The image shows Trotter’s method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis.

Option a: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).

Option c: McGovern’s technique is used in choanal atresia - A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway.

Option D: Valsalva maneuver is performed by forceful attempted exhalation against a closed nose and mouth. It is used as a test of cardiac function and autonomic nervous control of the heart, or to clear the ears and sinuses.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man came to you for nutritional advice. He is an alcoholic. Which of the following measures would not prevent the development of Wernicke's encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, vitamin C supplementation would not prevent the development of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

In an alcoholic person, thiamine deficiency can cause Wernicke's encephalopathy. Hence, the measures to prevent thiamine deficiency are:

  • Cessation of alcohol (Option A) 
  • Including gingelly seeds (sesame seeds) in the diet because they have the highest content of thiamine. (Option B)
  • Consuming parboiled rice instead of milled or highly polished rice. Thiamine is lost from rice during the process of milling. (Option C)
  • Direct supplementation with thiamine.

The two principal deficiency diseases of thiamine are:

  1. Beriberi may occur in three main forms :
    • The dry form is characterized by nerve involvement (peripheral neuritis)
    • The wet form is characterized by heart involvement (cardiac beriberi)
    • The infantile form is seen in infants between 2 to 4 months of age. The affected baby is usually breast-fed by a thiamine-deficient mother who commonly shows signs of peripheral neuropathy.
  2. Wernicke's encephalopathy is often seen often in alcoholics. It is characterized by ophthalmoplegia, polyneuritis, ataxia and mental deterioration. It occurs occasionally in people who fast.

High-risk groups for thiamine deficiency are:

  • Lactating mothers
  • Patients on regular haemodialysis
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Prolonged gastric aspiration 
  • People who go on long fasts

High-risk groups should be treated with direct supplementation of thiamine.

Note: Vitamin C supplementation in the dose of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

questions.text: The lactose operon is likely to be transcribed when ______

choices.text: There is more glucose in the cell than lactose
There is glucose but no lactose in the cell
Cyclic AMP and lactose levels are both high within the cell

questions.solution:
The lac operon is induced only when cyclic AMP and lactose levels are both high within the cell.

A small amount of lactose is converted to an isomer, allolactose that binds to the repressor protein, changing its conformation so that it can no longer bind to the operator.

In the absence of glucose, adenylyl cyclase is active, and sufficient quantities of cAMP are made and bind to the CAP protein.

The cAMP–CAP trans-acting complex binds to the CAP-binding site, causing RNA polymerase to more efficiently initiate transcription at the promoter site.

This is an example of positive control.

questions.text: A soldier underwent a left below-knee amputation after a  terrorist attack with explosives. He was brought to your department for fixing the below prosthesis.   Which level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Strategies to reduce impairment with prostheses fall under the tertiary level of prevention. 

Tertiary prevention includes all rehabilitation measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities, and minimize suffering caused by any stage of the disease. This also promotes the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions. Tertiary prevention extends the concepts of prevention by rehabilitation.

Examples include occupational and physical therapy in burn patients, and cardiac rehabilitation in post-myocardial infarction patients.

Other options:

Option B- Secondary prevention includes early disease detection, and its target is healthy-appearing individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. This is defined as the action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications. Screening tests and early diagnosis are the specific interventions used in the secondary level of prevention and they help to arrest the disease process.  

Option C- Primary prevention is defined as an action taken before the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Primary prevention is obtained by measures promoting general health and well-being, and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures. This helps in the modification of risk factors of a disease.  

Option D- Primordial prevention consists of risk factor reduction targeted towards an entire population through a focus on social and environmental conditions. Measures taken in this level of prevention are typically promoted through laws and national policies. The main intervention in primordial prevention is by individual and mass education.

questions.text: Decrease in pH shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to_____

choices.text: On either side depending on other factors

questions.solution:
The pH decreasing from the normal value shifts the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve, to the right.

Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve (OHDC)

  • This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2.
  • It is normally sigmoid-shaped.
  • If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favors O2 delivery) i.e. higher the P50 - Right shift Releases oxygen

Shift to the right is caused by: (Conditions with an increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat 
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anemia - reduced affinity for O2

Conditions that cause a left shift in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are:

  • Increased oxygen
  • Decreased carbon dioxide
  • Increased pH
  • Decreased temperature
  • Decreased 2,3-Biphosphoglycerate.
  • Fetal hemoglobin

questions.text: The cherry red spot seen in the image below is seen in _______.
questions.solution:
The image shows a cherry-red spot, which is a feature of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

Pathophysiology of the cherry-red spot:

A cherry-red spot of the macula is typical and arises in this area because of the absence of ganglion cells at the foveola resulting in the transmission of the normal choroidal color. This in contrast to the surrounding area where intense retinal whitening blocks the transmission of the normal choroidal color.

Risk factors of CRAO:

  • Heart disease
  • Carotid artery disease
  • Mucormycosis
  • Trauma

Clinical features of CRAO:

  • Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Severe edema: The whole retina looks white in color.
  • Marked attenuation of arteries: thread-like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in the artery and veins: cattle-track appearance
  • Cherry-red spot
  • Hollenhorst plaques - cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles.

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the intraocular pressure (IOP) by intravenous mannitol or ocular massage. The time limit is only 4 to 6 hours.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: At physiological pH, buffering action in blood is caused by which amino acid _______.
questions.solution:
At physiological pH, buffering action in blood is caused by histidine. 

The imidazole group of histidine has a pKa value of 6.5-7.4, which is close to physiological pH. 

Histidine is a positively charged amino acid which can exist in both its protonated (positively charged) and deprotonated (neutral) forms.

It acts as a buffer by accepting or donating protons (H+ ions) in response to changes in pH, helping to maintain the blood's pH within a narrow physiological range.

Hence, histidine has the maximum buffering capacity at physiological pH.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the outpatient department with fever and rash as shown below for the past 2 days. The rash was pleomorphic and first appeared on the trunk.  What is the secondary attack rate of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a pleomorphic rash are suggestive of chickenpox or varicella infection. The secondary attack rate of varicella infection is 70-90%. 

The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that disease occurs among susceptible persons following exposure to an infectious person within the range of the incubation period.

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of susceptible close contacts). The secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease. 

Varicella or chickenpox is a highly infectious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus. The mode of transmission from person to person is by droplet infection or by droplet nuclei. This virus can cross the placental barrier and cause congenital varicella.

The incubation period is usually 14 -16 days. The clinical course can be divided into 2 stages. The pre-eruptive stage is marked by the sudden onset of mild to moderate fever, back pain, shivering, and malaise. The eruptive stage is characterized by a rash that appears on the day of fever. They first appear on the trunk and then on the face, arms, and legs. It advances quickly through all stages of macule, papule, vesicle, and scab. Rash exhibits a characteristic feature called pleomorphism because all the above stages of rash may be seen simultaneously at one time. 

Most cases of chickenpox are mild and self-limiting. In children, acyclovir decreases symptoms if taken within 24 hours of the start of the rash, but it has no effect on complication rates, and it is not recommended for individuals with normal immune function.

Viral infection  Secondary attack rate

Measles ≥90%
Mumps 86%
Rubella 90%
Erythema infectiosum 10-60%
Infectious mononucleosis 10-20%

questions.text: Which of the following dural venous sinuses receives the great cerebral vein of Galen as its tributary?
questions.solution:
The venous sinus marked with 'B' in the given image is the straight sinus. The great cerebral vein of Galen drains into the straight sinus.

The straight sinus is a continuation of the inferior sagittal sinus. It lies in the junction of the falx cerebri with tentorium cerebelli. The straight sinus further drains into one of the transverse sinuses (mostly the left).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of fever chills, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea. He gives a history of consuming raw refrigerated cucumbers the previous day. What is the most likely etiologic organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Listeria monocytogenes.

It can survive at refrigerator temperatures (4°C), under conditions of low pH and high salt. So it is able to overcome food preservation and safety barriers, making it an important foodborne pathogen.

Healthy persons exposed to L. monocytogenes in food may not become ill or may develop a mild, self-limiting febrile gastroenteritis lasting 1–3 days. Symptoms include fever, chills, headache, myalgias, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Infection of pregnant women may lead to abortion or stillbirth. It may cause meningitis or sepsis in neonates due to perinatal transmission through an infected birth canal. Immunocompromised individuals can develop Listeria meningoencephalitis, bacteremia, and (rarely) focal infections.

The drug of choice is high dose intravenous ampicillin.

questions.text: A patient is planned to undergo tympanoplasty. In which type of tympanoplasty is the graft placed in contact with the structure marked in the given image, according to Wullstein's classification?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the incus. Type II tympanoplasty is performed when the malleus is eroded due to middle ear disease and the graft is placed on the incus.

The incus is one of the three ossicles of the middle ear. It has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic and can be identified by the long process that hangs vertically and attaches to the head of the stapes.

Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane. It involves ossiculoplasty (reconstruction of the ossicular chain) with or without myringoplasty.

The main objective of the procedure is the eradication of middle ear disease with the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane and ossicles.

Myringoplasty is the term given for the closure of perforation of pars tensa of tympanic membrane done to check repeated infections from the external ear.

Type Defect and repair
Type I Perforation of tympanic membrane which is repaired with a graft (myringoplasty)
Type II Perforation of tympanic membrane with erosion of malleus. The graft is placed on the incus or remnant of the malleus.
Type III Malleus and incus are absent. The graft is placed directly on the stapes head (myringostapediopexy)
Type IV Only the footplate of stapes is present. The graft is placed between the oval and round windows on the stapes footplate
Type V The stapes footplate is fixed but the round window is functioning. The graft is placed in contact with a new window created on the fenestra in the horizontal semicircular canal

 

Related Pearl: Zollner and Wullstein’s classification/ Types of tympanoplasty

Type Findings Procedure
Graft placed over
Type I (or) Myringoplasty All ossicles are intact Over/ under remnant TM over the handle of malleus
Type II Malleus eroded Over the remnant malleus/ incus
Type III (or) Columella (or) Myringostapediopexy Malleus & incus absent Over stapes superstructure
Type IV (or) Cavum minor All ossicles eroded Over ET and the round window, leaving mobile footplate expose
Type V (or) Fenestration surgery Fixed footplate An opening made in the lateral semicircular canal (an alternative pathway)
Type VI (or) Sono-Inversion --- The round window is left exposed and receives sound and the oval window is covered (reversed pathway)

Type III is called columella because it resembles the middle ear of birds. They have a single ossicle. Type VI is not part of the original Zollner-Wullstein classification. It is a recent addition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a neutralization test?
questions.solution:
Wassermann test is an example of a complement fixation test, not a neutralization test.

Wassermann test is a non-specific test for the diagnosis of syphilis. An antigen combines with its (specific) antibody in the presence of complement, and the antigen-antibody complex adsorbs the complement. This reaction is not visible and requires the use of an indicator (sheep erythrocytes and the specific anti-erythrocyte antibody).

Examples of neutralization tests include

  • Virus neutralization tests: Neutralization of viruses by antibodies.
    • Plaque inhibition test for neutralization of bacteriophages
  • Toxin neutralization tests: Bacterial exotoxins neutralization by antibodies
    • Nagler reaction: done for the detection of alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens
    • Schick test: Neutralization of diphtheria toxin by circulating antitoxin
    • Anti-streptolysin O test: Neutralization of streptococcal O hemolysin produced by beta-hemolytic streptococci.

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: A 30-year-old athlete injures his leg. He complains of pain in his knees. The following technique has been employed to alleviate his pain. Choose the false statement regarding the mechanism behind this technique.

choices.text: Operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
Based on the inhibition of pain pathway in the spinal cord.
Local lateral inhibition of interneurons occurs in the spinal cord.

questions.solution:
The given image shows transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief. It is based on the gate control theory of pain. This method uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibres (not inhibition) near the injury to relieve pain.

Gate control theory is based on the inhibition of pain pathways in the spinal cord. Various sensory inputs from a particular dermatome reach the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. The pain is transmitted via A-delta and C fibers, whereas, A-beta fibers carry tactile sensations (touch, pressure) and A-alpha fibers carry proprioception.

When these large-diameter A-beta/A-alpha fibres are stimulated, they inhibit the pain pathway in the spinal cord. This inhibition is thought to result from the local lateral inhibition of interneurons in the spinal cord.

Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

questions.text: Enzyme level tested in thiamine deficiency is:
questions.solution:
Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase provides an index of vitamin B1 nutritional status. Thiamine pyrophosphate (vit B1) is the cofactor of transketolase.

Transketolase reaction requires two cofactors:

  • Mg2+
  • Thiamine diphosphate (vitamin B1)

Transketolase and transaldolase are involved in the non oxidative phase of HMP pathway.

Other options:

Option A: Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane. It catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA which enters the citric acid/Kreb’s cycle.

Option B: Pyruvate kinase is involved in substrate-level phosphorylation to form 2× ATP per molecule of glucose oxidized. The reaction of pyruvate kinase is essentially irreversible under physiological conditions. It is involved in regulation of glycolysis

Option D: Transaldolase is involved in the non oxidative phase of HMP pathway.

questions.text: The cephalic index is used for the identification of:
questions.solution:
Cephalic Index is used to determine the race of the individual.

Cranial index = Maximum skull breadth x 100 / Maximum skull length

There are three main racial groups: Caucasian, Mongoloid and Negroid.

All the skulls cannot be accurately differentiated into the 3 broad categories because of the racial mixing.

The skull offers the best evidence on racial origins.

Type of skull Cephalic index Race(s)
Dolichocephalic 70-74.9 Pure Aryans, Aborigines, Negroes
Mesaticephalic 75-79.9 Europeans, Chinese, Indians
Brachycephalic 80-84.9 Mongolian

 

The skull of an Indian is 'Caucasian with a few Negroid features'.

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The above image is of a joule burn. It is formed at the point of contact with electricity. It is more popularly referred to as 'electrical burns' or 'electrical Marks.' Electrical burns may not always be evident, even in cases of fatal electrocutions as it is dependent on a number of factors like contact area, duration, presence of intervening moisture etc. 

Soot-soiling occurs from the person holding a shotgun barrel.

  • In tight flesh contact wounds, soot soiling and muzzle marks are uncommon. If there is loose contact or clothes are interposed, there may be soiling or muzzle marks.
  • In a case involving a close-range shotgun injury, if a victim catches the barrel of the gun, there may be soot-soling of the hands.

Frost Bite:

Above is the image of frostbite. It occurs when the body is exposed to cold temperatures.

Scalding:

Scalds are due to exposure to wet heat like hot water or steam.

questions.text: A toddler has been consuming excessive amounts of vitamin A-containing foods in the diet. The child has dry-flaky skin, frequent headaches,  episodic vomiting, and splenomegaly. Which of the following findings would likely be seen on taking an X-ray of the long bones?
questions.solution:
The history of excessive vitamin A consumption along with scaly, itchy skin, headache, vomiting (suggestive of pseudotumor cerebri), and splenomegaly, all point towards a diagnosis of hypervitaminosis A. In this condition, x-ray of the long bones would most likely show hyperostosis.

Hypervitaminosis A refers to the excessive consumption of vitamin A. Amounts greater than 6,000 micrograms per day in children can be toxic. As vitamin A is fat soluble, it cannot be excreted in the urine leading to accumulation in the liver and various other tissues.

This stored vitamin will continue to exert toxic effects on the body, even if consumption is stopped. In young children, hypervitaminosis A can present with headache, vomiting, and even bulging fontanelles. Pseudotumor cerebri (with elevated intracranial pressure), can present with diplopia and even papilledema. There can also be patches of itchy, desquamating skin. Abdominal examination may reveal hepatosplenomegaly.

Bones may show hyperostosis on x-ray. This is an overgrowth of bone, commonly along the middle part of the shafts of long bones. 

Stopping further consumption is the only way to manage this condition.

The image below depicts hyperostosis-

Other options-

Option (A): Salt and pepper sign is seen in the skull in primary hyperparathyroidism. This disorder causes demineralization and resorption of bone, resulting in pathological fractures, bone erosions, etc. 

The image below shows the salt and paper appearance of the skull-

Option (C): Bone cysts can be simple or aneurysmal. They are usually incidental findings on radiographs. Sometimes these cysts can present with pain due to recurrent bleeding or pathological fractures. Bones cysts can sometimes be seen in hyperparathyroidism as well.

The image below depicts a bone cyst in the humerus-

Option (D): Decreased bone density can be seen most commonly in osteoporosis. The most common causes for this decreased bone mineral density are- vitamin D deficiency, gonadal sex steroid deficiency, hyperparathyroidism, decreased bone formation with age, etc.

The image below demonstrates decreased bone density in osteoporosis-

questions.text:
Which of the following epithelia are correctly matched with their site?
Epithelium - Site
A. Transitional epithelium - Prostatic urethra
B. Stratified squamous epithelium - Membranous urethra
C. Pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia - Epididymis

D. Ciliated columnar epithelium - Fallopian tube
questions.solution:
Options A, C, and D are correctly matched.

Pseudostratified columnar epithelium lines the membranous urethra.

The following are various parts of the urethra in males and their lining epithelium:

  • Pre-prostatic & Prostatic urethra - Transitional epithelium
  • Membranous urethra - Pseudostratified columnar epithelium
  • Penile/ Spongy urethra - proximally, Pseudostratified columnar; distally, stratified squamous.

The epididymis contains pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia which help to increase the surface area for absorption.

The ciliated columnar epithelium is found in most of the respiratory tract, the uterus, and the uterine tube (oviduct), efferent ductules of the testis, parts of the middle ear and auditory tube; the ependyma lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the development of purple toe syndrome, after starting a new drug for the treatment of deep vein thrombosis, is suggestive of the adverse effect of warfarin.

Purple toe syndrome is a rare complication of warfarin therapy. It occurs due to cholesterol microemboli released from atheromatous plaques, which cause arteriolar occlusion. Warfarin must be immediately stopped and replaced with an oral factor Xa inhibitor (e.g. apixaban).
 
Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X and proteins C and S are done by carboxylation of their glutamate residues, with the help of the reduced form of vitamin K as a co-factor. This reduced form of vitamin K needs to be constantly recycled back from its oxidized form for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is competitively inhibited by warfarin. Hence, there will be a reduction in the activation of coagulation factors.

The image below shows warfarin's mechanism of action.

The half-life of proteins C and S are 8 and 24 hours, respectively, which is relatively shorter than the half-lives of other clotting factors, particularly factor II. Therefore, the full antithrombotic effect of warfarin is not achieved for 4 to 5 days. For this reason, warfarin must be bridged with a rapidly acting parenteral anticoagulant, such as heparin, low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), or fondaparinux, in patients with thrombosis or at high risk for thrombosis.

Uses of warfarin are acute deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and preventing stroke or systemic embolization in patients with a mechanical heart valve. 

Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation).

The therapeutic dose of warfarin is monitored by an INR range of 2-3. Warfarin toxicity can occur when the INR exceeds 4 and can lead to fatal bleeding. Treatment includes withholding warfarin, with vitamin K, and blood transfusions or fresh frozen plasma to replenish clotting factors.

Warfarin, LMWH, and UFH do not accumulate in breast milk and do not have an anticoagulant effect in the newborn. They are compatible with breastfeeding.

Warfarin is mainly metabolized by the CYP2C9 enzyme. Drugs that affect the CYP2C9 enzyme can alter the anticoagulant function of warfarin and these include the following:

Reduced efficacy:

  • CYP2C9 activation by drugs: barbiturates, carbamazepine, rifampin
  • Oral contraceptives: increase blood levels of clotting factors

Increased efficacy:

  • Drugs causing CYP2C9 inhibition:
    • Amiodarone
    • Azole antifungals
    • Cimetidine
    • Clopidogrel
    • Cotrimoxazole
    • Disulfiram
    • Isoniazid
    • Metronidazole
    • Fluoxetine
    • Sulfinpyrazone
    • Zafirlukast

Other options:

Option B: Heparin acts by activating antithrombin III, thereby inactivating the active form of clotting factors II, IX, X, XI, XII, and XIII. Adverse effects are bleeding and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) due to the formation of antibodies against the heparin-platelet complex.

Option C: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor. It is used for the prevention of embolism and stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Bleeding and dyspepsia are the most important adverse effects.

Option D: Rivaroxaban is a direct inhibitor of factor Xa. It is used for prophylaxis and treatment of deep vein thrombosis. Side effects reported are bleeding, nausea, hypotension, tachycardia, and edema.
