questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the beneficiaries of the scheme that has the logo shown below?

choices.text: It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
It provides health insurance of upto 1,00,000 Rs. per family per year.
Service is provided to families with a maximum of 5 members.
The insurance is provided in the form of cash to the families.

questions.solution:
The image shows the logo of the Ayushman Bharat scheme. The correct statement is Option A - It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.

Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission (AB-NHPM) aims to build a comprehensive need-based health care service and targets to build a 'New India 2022'. Its components are:

  • The first component is the creation of 1,50,000 Health & Wellness Centres (HWCs) to deliver comprehensive primary health care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services and non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services.
  • The second component is the Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY), which provides health insurance cover of Rs. 5 lakhs per year to over 10 crore poor and vulnerable families seeking secondary and tertiary care.

Benefits under the scheme:

  • The government provides health insurance coverage of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year(Option B).
  • All families listed in the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database as per the defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members (Option C).
  • Priority is given to a girl child, women, and senior citizens.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empanelled private hospitals in times of need.
  • It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
  • 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, the cost of medicines, and diagnostics.
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services (Option D).
  • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.
  • A 24X7 helpline number is available for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances.

The instrument shown in the image is Jackson’s double-lumen metal tracheostomy tube.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

Low tracheostomy

  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: What is culture contact also known as?
questions.solution:
Culture contact is also known as acculturation.

Acculturation is the process by which there is the diffusion of cultures between two culturally different groups of people. This can happen in the following ways:

  • Trade and commerce
  • Industrialization
  • Religious propagation
  • Education
  • Conquest

Acculturation can influence people in both good and bad ways. Widespread use of tobacco is a bad example of acculturation. However, the introduction of scientific medicine is a good example of acculturation.

Other options -

Options A and C - Customs are the traditionally accepted ways of behaving that are specific to a society. They can be folkways, which are referred to as the right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct. Mores are stringent customs followed by society.

Option D - Role is the function or duties assumed by a person of a particular society.

Note: Socialization is defined as a process by which man acquires beliefs, customs, traditions, and prejudices of society due to his everyday interaction with people of the society.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the image given below:

choices.text: It is called Argyl Robertson pupil
The vision is normal in right eye
Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes

questions.solution:
The image suggests Marcus Gunn pupil, which is seen in optic neuritis. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal.

  • The condition is named after the scientist, Marcus Gunn who belongs to Scotland.
  • Marcus Gunn pupil refers to the paradoxical response of the pupil to light in the presence of a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
  • It is confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test.
  • The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response observed.
  • Normally, both pupils remain constricted.
  • In the presence of RAPD, when the flashlight is moved from the normal to the abnormal eye, both pupils dilate.
  • It is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease.

questions.text: What is reverse hypopyon?

choices.text: Collection of pus in the vitreous
Collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber

questions.solution:
Reverse hypopyon is the collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber.

Silicone oil is the vitreous substitute that is injected into the vitreous cavity after vitrectomy.

When it gets emulsified, it enters the anterior chamber and collects in the upper part.

Complications of silicone oil in the anterior chamber:

  • Glaucoma
  • Band-shaped keratopathy

Image: Reverse hypopyon

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. Her symptoms have progressed gradually over the past 4 weeks. Which of the following signs/syndrome is seen in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is a typical presentation of Gradenigo’s Syndrome, which occurs secondary to petrositis (a complication of otitis media).

Gradenigo’s syndrome is a triad that consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (VI nerve palsy)
  • Deep ear/facial pain (V Nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

Other options:

Option A: Griesinger’s sign is mastoid tenderness and edema, which is secondary to thrombophlebitis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis.

Option C: Grisel syndrome refers to atlantoaxial joint subluxation. It is associated with the overuse of diathermy either for the removal of the adenoid or following curettage when used for hemostasis. The patient complains of neck pain and develops torticollis.

Option D: Holman-Miller sign or antral sign is the anterior bowing of the maxillary wall due to the presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space on a CT scan. Holman-Miller sign is a pathognomonic feature of angiofibroma.

questions.text: The mutations/changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except?
questions.solution:
Enhancer deletion does not convert a proto-oncogene to oncogene.

Mechanisms of Activating Oncogenes:

Mechanism Explanation
Mutation A classic example is the point mutation of the RAS oncogene. This results in the gene product, a small GTPase, having less activity in tumors and in resultant stimulation of the activity of adenylyl cyclase. 
Promoter insertion  Insertion of a viral promoter region near a gene activates it. 
Enhancer insertion  Insertion of a viral enhancer region near a gene activates it. 
Chromosomal translocation  The basis is that a piece of one chromosome is split off and joined to another. Classic examples are these involved in Burkitt lymphomaand in the Philadelphia chromosome 
Gene amplification   Abnormal multiplication of a gene occurs, resulting in many copies. This can occur with oncogenes and also genes involved in tumordrug resistance.

questions.text: As a part of the pre-operative evaluation of a patient posted for cataract surgery, you are asked to calculate the power of the intraocular lens to be implanted. What investigation would you perform?
questions.solution:
The investigation commonly performed for calculating the power of the intraocular lens (IOL) is a keratometry. Biometry can also be done.

The power of an intraocular lens (IOL) is calculated using a biometer and the procedure is termed biometry. Optical coherence biometry is a non-contact method of axial length measurement. Modern biometry devices also perform keratometry, anterior chamber depth, and corneal measurement, and are able to calculate IOL power using a range of formulae. 

 The most common method of determining IOL power uses a regression formula called SRK formula, which is given below:

 P = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

Where, 

  • P is the power of IOL
  • A is a constant, which is specific for each lens type
  • L is the axial length of the eyeball in millimeters, determined by using the A-scan ultrasonography
  • K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

 The images given below show a biometer and the keratometer respectively.  

A-scan ultrasonography is used for determining the axial length of the eyeball. It can be acquired by direct contact or by using a water bath over the eye (immersion ultrasonography). Unfortunately, it is a slightly less accurate method of determining the axial dimension.

The sound beam must be aligned with the visual axis for maximal precision. Each reflecting surface is represented by a spike on the oscilloscope monitor. A-scan ultrasonography is shown in the image below.

Other options: 

Pachymetry measures corneal thickness. It is shown in the image below.

 

Tonometry measures intraocular pressure. It is shown in the image below.

 

Gonioscopy is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber. It also aids in the localization of the foreign body, abnormal blood vessels, or tumors in the angle. The given instrument below is an indirect gonioscope.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with acute loss of vision and metamorphopsia. There is a history of the positive scotoma. Fundal changes are given below. What will be the fundus fluorescein angiography finding?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the fundal image depicting focal fundal detachment is suggestive of central serous retinopathy. An enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern is seen in FFA.

Central serous retinopathy

  • Refers to the spontaneous serous detachment of neurosensory retina in the macular region.
  • Pathogenesis: Recent studies implicate an abnormal choroidal circulation as the cause of CSR. 

Clinical features:

  • Retinal detachment: Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Relative positive scotoma
  • Micropsia
  • Metamorphopsia

Investigations:

  • Ophthalmoscopy 
    • Circular ring reflex present
    •  Foveal reflex absent
  • FFA 
    •  Enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern

Treatment: 

  • Treatment not required, usually self-limiting but often recurrent
  • Steroids are contraindicated.

Other options:

  • Petaloid appearance: Cystoid macular edema
  • Stars in the sky appearance: Drusen
  • Dual circulation: Choroidal melanoma

questions.text: Photostress test is used to differentiate between _______.
questions.solution:
Photostress test is used to differentiate between diseases involving the macula and those involving the optic nerve.

In this test, one eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on the near chart. A bright light is then shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again; the time taken to recover is noted. The test is repeated with the other eye.

In normal persons and in patients with optic nerve disease, the recovery time is not affected. However, in patients with macular disease, the recovery time is prolonged and is usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time. This is because, in macular disease, the photoreceptors are damaged, and there is a delay in the visual pigment regeneration process.

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease?
questions.solution:
Apolipoprotein E4 is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • MMSE < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4, Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: Hallucinations
  • Dyspraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • Urinary incontinence

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles, neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: Memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: Donepezil, Galantamine, Rivastigmine.

questions.text: The structure marked in the cadaveric image given below, arises at the ______
questions.solution:
The marked structure can be identified as the superior mesenteric artery, as it lies anterior and superior to the left renal vein. The superior mesenteric artery originated from the abdominal aorta at the level of the lower border of the L1 vertebra, about 1 cm below the celiac trunk .

Their branches are:

  • Jejunal branches
  • Ileal branches
  • Middle colic artery
  • Right colic artery
  • Ileocolic artery
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Clinical note - Nutcracker syndrome:

  • The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, appears in the sagittal plane, as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein).
  • This condition is called nutcracker (left renal vein entrapment) syndrome.

questions.text: A child has congenital cataract involving the visual axis, which was detected at birth. When should the child be operated up on?

choices.text: At 1 year of age, when the globe attains normal size
At 4 years, when ocular and orbital growth is complete

questions.solution:
The ideal age for cataract surgery in children is 4 to 6 weeks because 6 weeks is the critical period for visual maturation in children.

A unilateral cataract is more dangerous than a bilateral cataract because the risk of amblyopia is greater. 

Under-correction of intraocular lens (IOL) power is needed in children.

In children < 2 years of age:

In unilateral cases, primary implantation is indicated as soon as the patient is fit for anesthesia, ideally between 2 and 3 months of age. The power is undercorrected by 20%. The earlier the surgery is done, the better the chance that deep amblyopia can be overcome.

In children between 2 and 8 years of age:

    • An IOL is implanted but power is undercorrected by 10%.
    • An in-the-bag IOL is chosen for children above 1 year of age because they are less likely to need an IOL exchange.

Beyond 8 years, IOL power is the same as the calculated value

questions.text: The incision preferred during autopsy in case of asphyxial death due to neck compression is?
questions.solution:
The incision preferred in the case of asphyxial death due to neck compression is the modified Y-shaped incision.

In strangulation, hanging, and any condition where the larynx might be damaged, modified Y-shaped incision is to be preferred, as the skin of the upper neck can then be dissected off the mandible and raised clear to give a wide approach to the neck structures.

Y-Shaped Incision: Commences at anterior axillary fold on the chest on either side, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at xiphisternum in the midline and then run downwards as in I-shaped incision to the symphysis pubis. It is preferred in females. It is more cosmetically accepted as the incision and the stitches are minimally seen after the autopsy. 

Modified Y-shaped incision: An incision is made in the midline from the suprasternal notch to the symphysis pubis. The incision extends from suprasternal notch over the clavicle to its center on both sides and then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear. Indicated in cases of strangulation or death due to compression of the neck. 

I-Shaped Incision: Extends from symphysis mentii to symphysis pubis taking curve towards left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice. It is simple and convenient.

Elongated X-shaped Incision: This is a special incision used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries, which are usually missed where superficial imprints are faint, particularly when present on skin not overlying bone. This is helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death and should be practiced in cases of custodial death.

Note: This MCQ has been revised for factual accuracy. For a detailed explanation about the incisions, refer to the link - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539901/ .

questions.text: The section of the IPC dealing with ‘causing hurt by means of poisons’ is:
questions.solution:
Section 328 IPC deals with 'causing hurt by means of poisons, etc.'

  • Section 320 IPC - Grievous hurt
  • Section 324 IPC - Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means

questions.text: Which of the following bones is most accurate for sex determination?
questions.solution:
The whole pelvis is the most reliable bone for sex determination.

Krogman’s degree of accuracy in sex determination from adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones alone – 80-90%
  • Long bones and skull - 90-95%
  • Long bones and pelvis - >95%

Related Pearl: Indices for determination of race and sex of an individual

To determine the sex of an individual -

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones alone – 80%

questions.text: Which of the following does not apply to a 15-year-old child, under the Factories Act, 1948?

choices.text: The child should not be made to work for more than 4 & 1/2 hours.
The child is allowed to take leave once every 15 days.
The child can work between 6AM and 7PM.
Children of this age are prohibited from working.

questions.solution:
According to the Factories Act of 1948, children aged 15 years are not prohibited from working; all other options are provisions for children aged 15 years.

Under the Factories Act of 1948, children below 14 years of age are prohibited from working.

  • Provisions of the Factories Act, of 1948, for adolescents between 15 and 18 years:
    • They can work only between 6 AM and 7 PM
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days
    • They are restricted from working in dangerous occupations

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

  • The act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 
  • Age of employment –  prohibition children of < 14 years from working.
  • Adolescents between 15 – 18 years
    • Can be employed  only in certain industries and  work between 6 AM – 7 PM
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours
    • They are allowed to take leave once in every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days
  • Hours of work for adults: maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day, if working overtime then it should be no more than 60 hrs per week
  • Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person
  • Safety and Welfare measures:
    • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
    • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
    • > 250 Workers – Canteen
    • > 50 Workers- Crèche*

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law which has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers- 12 weeks to 26 weeks
  • Working mothers, already with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

 

*for fifty women worker after the 1976 amendment.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child has a history of biting his lips and fingers. On evaluation, you notice lip lacerations, missing portions of fingers of his hands, and developmental delay. On inquiry, the parents say that two male cousins on the mother's side with similar complaints have been diagnosed with a genetic disorder. Lab reports reveal hyperuricemia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of self-mutilating behavior, delayed developmental milestones, positive family history and hyperuricemia is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It occurs due to the complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) involved in the salvage pathway.

Purines produced in the body or introduced through diet can be converted to nucleoside triphosphates to be reused by the body. This pathway is called the salvage pathway for purines and is shown below

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the HGPRT enzyme. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine resulting in increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) and decreased levels of inosine monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP). An increase in guanine and hypoxanthine eventually gets converted into uric acid, There is increased de novo purine synthesis.

The clinical features include compulsive self-mutilation, intellectual disability, delayed milestones, dystonic movements, and hyperuricemia. The excess uric acid can form kidney stones (urolithiasis) or deposits in joints as urate crystals (gouty arthritis).

The treatment of this condition includes:

  • Allopurinol or febuxostat for hyperuricemia
  • Behavioural management using restraints for self-mutilation
  • High fluid intake, reduced fructose and purine intake

Partial deficiency of HGPRT leads to Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency leads to severe T-cell deficiency with normal B-cell function. Patients present with autoimmune diseases and opportunistic infections.

Option C: Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRT) is another enzyme along with HGPRT to be involved in the salvage of purine bases to nucleotides. 

Option D: Adenosine deaminase deficiency leads to sparse or defective T cells and B cells. Patients suffer from severe immunodeficiency and often succumb to fatal infections. 

 

Related Pearl: Purine salvage deficiencies: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and Adenosine deaminase deficiency(SCID)

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency(SCID):

Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann–Riniker syndrome.

SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections early in life and often present with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

It is due to deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase(HGPRT). It is an X-linked recessive disease.

Clinical features:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Self-mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Hyperuricemia 
  • Gout

Treatment:

  • Allopurinol
  • Febuxostat

Related Pearl: Enzymes and Steps Involved in Purine Degradation

Enzymes

Reaction

AMP deaminase

AMP to IMP

Adenosine deaminase

Adenosine to Inosine

5'-nucleotidase

IMP & GMP to Inosine & Guanosine respectively

Purine nucleoside phosphorylase

Inosine & Guanosine to Hypoxanthine & guanine respectively

Xanthine oxidase

Hypoxanthine to Xanthine & Xanthine to uric acid

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding neutrophil extracellular trapping (NET) except that

choices.text: It is detected in blood during sepsis.
It is produced in response to bacterial infection.
It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes.

questions.solution:
Mitochondrial DNA is not seen in neutrophil extracellular traps (NET).

Neutrophilic extracellular traps are networks of extracellular fibers that provide a high concentration of antimicrobial substances at the site of infection and prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils.

Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are the meshwork of nuclear chromatin of neutrophils. The loss of nuclei leads to the death of the neutrophils. They concentrate on antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to fight against bacteria and fungi (not viruses) (option D). They are detected in the blood during sepsis (option A). They are produced by neutrophils in response to:

  • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi (option B).
  • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

Note: The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A patient is advised to be isolated in a separate room after he was diagnosed with an air-borne infection. What is the infection that requires these kind of measures?
questions.solution:
Isolation in a separate room is mandatory for measles among the given options. It is transmitted by droplet infection as well as via the airborne route. The period of isolation is from the onset of symptoms (catarrhal stage) through the fourth day of the rash.

Isolation is defined as the separation of an infected person or animal for the period of communicability in places to prevent direct or indirect transmission to susceptible individuals. 

Measles is an infectious disease mainly seen in the childhood age group. It is caused by an RNA paramyxovirus and is transmitted to humans primarily by droplet infection and also through airborne transmission.

Features include:

  • The prodromal phase-characterized by fever, cough, coryza, and Koplik's spots which are rashes seen in the buccal mucosa opposite the first and second molar. 
  • The eruptive phase- macular or maculopapular rash begins behind the ears and spreads to the face, neck, and extremities.
  • Post measles phase is characterized by weight loss.

Some of the complications of measles include otitis media, laryngotracheobronchitis (croup), diarrhea, post-infectious measles, or subacute sclerosing pan encephalitis (SSPE). Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a rare but fatal complication. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at supportive care such as relieving the symptoms, treating dehydration, and isolating patients.

The below images show a characteristic rash in measles and Koplik's spots on the buccal mucosa. 

Other options:

Option B: Rabies is transmitted via a bite or scratch from an infected animal. Contraction of rabies by inhalation of virus-containing aerosols is extremely rare. Human-to-human transmission is possible but has not been confirmed.

Option C: Nipah is transmitted mainly from direct contact with sick pigs or their contaminated tissues. To prevent human-to-human transmission, close unprotected contact with infected people is avoided. Regular hand hygiene should be followed when caring for or visiting infected people.

Option D: If the diagnosis is confirmed as aseptic meningitis, the patient can often be discharged home. Isolation is required if the meningitis is of infectious etiology.

questions.text: A first-year medical student is doing a meticulous dissection of the thoracic cage in a human cadaver. During dissection, he sees an osseo-aponeurotic opening in the diaphragm transmitting a large vessel. Which among the following other structures can be seen passing through the same opening?

choices.text: Left vagus nerve and thoracic duct
Right vagus nerve and thoracic duct

questions.solution:
The osseo-aponeurotic opening in the diaphragm transmits the aorta. The other structures which pass through the same opening are the azygous vein and the thoracic duct. 

It is the most posteroinferior of the three larger openings in the diaphragm and lies at the level of the T12 vertebra. It is bounded laterally by the two diaphragmatic crura, the vertebral column posteriorly, and anteriorly by the median arcuate ligament.

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: The artery of the pterygoid canal is a branch of ______ part of maxillary artery.
questions.solution:
The artery of the pterygoid canal is a branch of pterygopalatine part of the maxillary artery.

Pterygopalatine branches of maxillary artery are (mnemonic PIGPAS):

  • Posterior superior alveolar artery
  • Infraorbital artery
  • Greater palatine artery
  • Pharyngeal artery
  • Artery of pterygoid canal
  • Sphenopalatine artery

Related Pearl: Branches of maxillary artery

The maxillary artery is divided into three parts by the lateral pterygoid muscle.

  • The first part passes between the neck of the mandible and the sphenomandibular ligament and then along the lower border of the lateral pterygoid muscle.
  • The second part passes superficial to the lower head of the lateral pterygoid.
  • The third part passes between the two heads of lateral pterygoid muscle and then enters the pterygopalatine fossa by passing through the pterygomaxillary fissure

questions.text: Which murmur is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image given above is of an ejection systolic murmur.

This murmur starts after S1, increases in intensity to reach the peak, and ends before A2.

Ejection systolic murmur(ESM) is most commonly heard in aortic stenosis and in pulmonary stenosis. They are differentiated based on the difference in symptoms, site of murmur, etc.

Auscultation of ESM in aortic stenosis.

  • In the early stages, an early systolic ejection sound may be heard. It disappears when the valve becomes calcified and rigid.
  • As the stenosis worsens, the LV systole gets prolonged and there is delayed closure of the aortic valve. This leads to the narrowing of S2 sound, and in severe cases, it might lead to the paradoxical splitting of S2.
  • S4 and S3 sounds may be heard in severe cases when the diastolic and systolic functions of the left ventricle have been reduced.
  • Murmur: The murmur in aortic stenosis is an ejection systolic murmur. The murmur radiates to the neck and base of the heart. It is augmented by squatting and reduced by the strain of the Valsalva maneuver.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect
Inspiration (↑venous return to right atrium) ↑ intensity of right sided sounds
Hand grip (↑afterload ) ↑ intensity of MR, AR and VSD murmurs
↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
MVP: delayed onset of click / murmur
Valsalva-Phase II, standing up (↓ preload) ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur
Rapid squatting (↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)		 ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
↑ intensity of AS, MR and VSD murmurs
MVP: later onset of click / murmur

questions.text: After administration of a drug for an acute attack of migraine, a patient developed nausea and vomiting. She also developed tingling and numbness in the tip of the finger that eventually turned blue. Which of the following is the most likely drug implicated in the above findings?
questions.solution:
Nausea and vomiting, as well as tingling and numbness (paresthesia), are common adverse effects of dihydroergotamine.

The numbness progressing to bluish discoloration of the fingers are the initial signs of occlusion. It can eventually lead to gangrene if left untreated. This is a rare adverse effect of dihydroergotamine.

Contraindications for ergotamine: 

  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Uncontrolled hypertension
  • Fever and/or sepsis
  • Pregnancy
  • Within 24 hours of using triptans

questions.text: Which of the following is an example for GPCR receptor?
questions.solution:
Muscarinic receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors among the given options.

Nicotinic and GABA-A are examples of ion channel coupled receptors while the insulin receptor is a tyrosine kinase receptor.

questions.text: Hormone(s) required during puberty_____
questions.solution:
GH, leptin, and testosterone are all required for the onset of puberty.

The onset of puberty is marked by enhanced androgenic activity.

The growth spurt of adolescent males is influenced by a complex interplay between androgens, growth hormone (GH), nutrition, and genetic factors.

Leptin, the satiety-producing hormone secreted by fat cells, maybe the link between body weight and puberty.

questions.text: Which of the following is most important for sodium and water retention in response to hypovolemia?
questions.solution:
The renin-angiotensin system plays a key role in body’s response to hypovolemia (refer figure).

The plasma concentration of renin is the rate-limiting step in the renin-angiotensin system; it is the major determinant of plasma angiotensin II concentration.

Angiotensin II stimulates the aldosterone and ADH secretion; it also constricts the blood vessels and causes thirst, which helps in maintaining blood pressure.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy presented with the deformity as shown below. Which nerve injury causes the given condition ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows extension at the metacarpophalangeal joint and flexion at interphalangeal joints of the ring and little finger, caused by ulnar nerve injury. It produces a claw hand (main en griffe). Leprosy can affect peripheral nerves and lead to their associated conditions.

In ulnar nerve palsy, only the medial two fingers develop clawing, while in a combined median and ulnar nerve palsy, all four fingers develop clawing. 

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals in the hand. The lumbricals have a combined action on metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint flexion and interphalangeal (IP) joint extension (glass holding posture). In ulnar nerve injury, since the medial lumbricals are not functional, the forearm muscles are unopposed. Hence, there is hyperextension at MCP joints and flexion at IP joints. This causes claw hand deformity. There is also numbness of the ulnar one and a half fingers. 

Elbow fractures or dislocations lead to high lesions of the ulnar nerve. Here, the hand is not markedly deformed because the ulnar half of the flexor digitorum profundus is paralyzed and the fingers, therefore, appear less clawed. This is called the high ulnar paradox.

The following tests are done to test the integrity of the ulnar nerve:

  • Egawa's test - In a positive test, due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger is weak.
  • Book test or Froment's sign - The patient is asked to hold a book forcefully while the doctor tries to pull it. In a positive test, due to weakness of adductor pollicis muscle, adduction of thumb is lost. The patient tries to hold the book by using flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the inter-phalangeal joint while holding the book.
  • Card test - In the case of weak palmar interossei, it is easy for the examiner to pull out the card when held between the fingers. This is due to the loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles.

Other options

Option B - In radial nerve palsy, the patient presents with 'wrist drop' in case of paralyzed wrist extensors, and 'finger drop' when extensor digitorum is paralyzed. When there is compression in the axilla, radial nerve palsy is called Saturday night palsy. There is paralysis of the triceps, and weakness of the wrist and hand. In high lesions, there is sensory loss on the dorsum of the hand over the anatomical stuff box. 

Option C - In median nerve injury, paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle leads to 'ape thumb' deformity. In forearm or elbow injuries, there is paralysis of long flexors of the thumb, index, and middle fingers, radial wrist flexors, and forearm pronators. This leads to the characteristic 'pointing index finger'. There is sensory loss over three and a half digits on the radial side. 

Option D -Posterior interosseous nerve injury, is seen in posterior interosseous syndrome. The wrist is in radial deviation and there is loss of metacarpophalangeal joint extension. However, wrist extension is preserved.

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids can form oxaloacetate?
questions.solution:
The amino acid Aspartate can be converted into oxaloacetate through a series of enzymatic reactions.

Oxaloacetate is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle (also known as the Krebs cycle or TCA cycle), a key metabolic pathway in cells that generates energy through the oxidation of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins.

Aspartate can be transaminated (an amino group transferred) to form oxaloacetate, which plays a crucial role in linking various metabolic pathways, including the citric acid cycle and gluconeogenesis (the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources).

Anaplerotic process is the replenishment of the intermediates of the citric acid (Krebs) cycle to replace the catalytic processes and to ensure the continuation of the cycle.

Transamination of aspartate to form oxaloacetate is one of these reactions.

Other anaplerotic reactions:

  • Carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which is catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase. 
  • Glutamate and glutamine to α-ketoglutarate, a reaction catalyzed by glutamate dehydrogenase and glutaminase, respectively
  • Compounds that produce propionyl CoA can be then carboxylated and isomerized to succinyl CoA.
  • Pyruvate can be carboxylated to malate.

Entry level in TCA cycle

Alpha keto-glutarate

  • Histidine
  • Glutamine
  • Proline
  • Glutamate
Succinyl CoA
  • Valine

questions.text: Barrier methods are all except:
questions.solution:
• Barrier methods of contraception include:
    • Physical methods – condoms, female condoms, diaphragm, vaginal sponge (Today).
    • Chemical methods – foam tablets and aerosols, creams and jellies, suppositories and soluble films.
  • Lippes loop is an intrauterine device.

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. All of the following organisms can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, except _______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics. All of the organisms mentioned in the options can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics except  Staphylococcus aureus

Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive coccus arranged in grape-like clusters. It causes various localized pyogenic infections like folliculitis, furuncle, abscess, impetigo, paronychia, osteomyelitis, and even septicemia.

Other options:

Option A: Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus. It causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is usually followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes. Itraconazole is the drug of choice for treatment.

Option C: Nocardia asteroides is a gram-positive aerobic bacteria. It is frequently found in the soil and infection may be exogenous. Cutaneous infections can present as local abscesses or lymphocutaneous lesions.

Option D: Mycobacterium marinum is a non-tuberculous mycobacterium. It causes swimming pool granuloma. The lesion begins as a papule and breaks down to form an indolent ulcer. It usually occurs after abrasions and is therefore seen on the prominences like elbows, knees, ankles, or toes.

The image below shows sporotrichosis.

questions.text: Which part of this bone is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa?
questions.solution:
The part of the scapula marked as 1 is the coracoid process and it is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa. The tip of the coracoid process lies approximately 2.5 cm below the clavicle, immediately lateral to the infraclavicular fossa (deltopectoral triangle). Hence, the coracoid process can be palpated below the clavicle.

The coracoid process arises from the upper border of the neck of the scapula and it projects forwards and slightly laterally. Attachments at the coracoid process include 

  • The conoid portion of the coracoclavicular ligament 
  • Pectoralis minor 
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament 
  • Glenocorocoid ligamnet 
  • Coracobrachialis muscle

Other options 

Option B - Acromian process continues from the spine of the scapula. The acromion is subcutaneous over its dorsal surface, The attachments at the acromion are the coracoacromial ligament, the articular capsule of the acromioclavicular joint, and horizontal fibers of the trapezius. 

Option C - The glenoid fossa is present at the lateral angle of the scapula. It is articular with the humerus to form the shoulder joint. 

Option D - The inferior angle lies over the seventh rib. Dorsally, it is related to latissimus dorsi. The angle is visible when the arm is raised over the head.

Parts of the scapula are given in the image below.

questions.text: A patient presents with findings as shown in the image below: 1) shows the site of the lesion,  2) has loss of proprioception, vibration, and discriminative touch 3) has loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion on the contralateral side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image along with the features above is diagnostic of Brown Sequard syndrome.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The part marked as 1 is the site of the lesion, at which hemisection of the cord is seen.

The part marked as 2 is the ipsilateral side of the lesion, which has the following features.

  • Loss of proprioception and vibration
  • Loss of discriminative touch
  • Weakness and spastic type of paralysis in certain muscle groups

The part marked as 3 is the contralateral side of the lesion and exhibits the following features

  • Loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with severe pain in the lower back radiating to the pubic symphysis. Ultrasonography revealed a stone in the left ureter, measuring 3 mm in size. The stone is most likely to be lodged in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Vesicoureteric junction is the narrowest part of the ureter.

This is the reason why stones as small as 2 to 3 mm get arrested in the vesicoureteric junction.

The ureter is constricted at 5 places:

  1. At the pelvi-ureteric junction
  2. At the brim of the lesser pelvis (as it crosses the common iliac artery)
  3. At the site of crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus.
  4. Vesico-ureteric junction
  5. At its opening in the lateral angle of the trigone

These are regarded as surgical constrictions of the ureter. However, the anatomical constrictions are only three of them (1, 2, and 4).

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with sudden onset dysarthria and impaired sensation over the right side of her face. Further examination shows loss of pain and temperature on the left side of the body. When asked to walk in a straight line, she sways to the right side. Which of the following marked vessels is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome/Wallenberg syndrome. This may result from a stroke affecting the ipsilateral (right-sided, in this case) vertebral artery marked as '4' in the image above.

Lateral medullary syndrome: The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal)- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of face.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb)
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body. 
  • IX and X CN - ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia, dysarthria.
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Descending sympathetic tract – ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

The lateral medullary syndrome may also occur as a consequence of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) stroke. PICA is a branch of the vertebral artery.

 

Other options:

The other structures marked in the image are as follows - 

1 - Anterior cerebral artery

2 - Middle cerebral artery

3 - Basilar cerebral artery

questions.text: The image given below shows an H&E-stained section of a lung tumor. Which of the following tumor markers are most likely to be expressed by immunohistochemical studies of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The above H&E stained histopathological image of a lung tumor shows keratin pearls suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Cytokeratins are the tumor markers that are most likely to be expressed.

Cytokeratins are the intermediate filaments expressed by epithelial cells. The presence of cytokeratins on immunohistochemistry suggests a carcinoma of epithelial origin. Tumors of epithelial origin include squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma, etc.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is commonly seen in men and has an increased risk with smoking. The tumor appears like a cauliflower-like mass that is gray-white, firm to hard, and bulky with haemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathological features include keratinization in the form of squamous pearls. The cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha-fetoprotein is a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis. 

Option B: Calretinin serves as a marker for mesothelioma.

Option C: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker for colon carcinoma and other malignancies including the pancreas, stomach, and heart.

questions.text:
The binding groove and effector cells associated with HLA class 1 molecules are:

HLA : Human Leukocyte Antigen

choices.text: Beta I and Alpha I, CD4 T cells
Beta II and Alpha I, CD4 T cells
Alpha I and Alpha II, CD8 T cells
Alpha II and Beta II, CD8 T cells

questions.solution:
The binding groove associated with human leukocyte antigen I (HLA I) is between its alpha 1 and alpha 2 domains, and the effector cells involved are CD8 T cells.

The human major histocompatibility complex (MHC) is called the HLA complex. MHC is a cluster of genes whose products are responsible for antigen presentation to T cells, transplant rejection, etc.

HLA complex of genes is present on the short arm of chromosome 6. It consists of three separate clusters of genes, labeled as class I, II, and III.

HLA class I molecules are present on all nucleated cells. They consist of a heavy peptide chain called the alpha chain that is linked to β-2 microglobulin, which is called the beta chain. The alpha chain further consists of three domains called alpha 1, 2 and 3 that protrude from the cell membrane, as shown in the image below.

There exists a groove between the alpha 1 and alpha 2 domains, where small peptides formed subsequent to protein antigens being processed by macrophages or dendritic cells, bind for presentation to CD8 T cells.

Following this, the CD8 cytotoxic killer cell destroys the target cell. However, the T cell can recognise the antigen only when presented as a complex with the MHC class I molecule and this is called MHC restriction.

HLA class I antigens are involved in graft rejections and cell-mediated cytolysis and are also components of hormone receptors.

HLA class II molecules are present on macrophages, dendritic cells, activated T cells and B cells. They too consist of an alpha and beta chain, each having a proximal and distal domain, as shown in the image below.

The antigen-binding site comprises the two distal domains, which are alpha 1 and beta 1 domains. Antigens are bound for recognition by CD4 T cells. They are principally involved in graft-versus-host-disease and mixed leukocyte reactions.

HLA class III molecules include complement components linked to the formation of C3 convertases, heat shock proteins and tumour necrosis factors.

questions.text: The porphyrin present in heme is  ______.
questions.solution:
The porphyrin present in heme is protoporphyrin. Heme is ferroprotoporphyrin. Iron is present in the ferrous state in heme.

Porphyrins are cyclic colored compounds formed by the linkage of four pyrrole rings through methyne or methenyl (=CH-) bridges. There are three types of porphyrins:

  • Uroporphyrin  (most water-soluble).
  • Coproporphyrin (intermediate).
  • Protoporphyrin (least water-soluble).

Related Pearl: Heme containing proteins

Protein Function
 Hemoglobin   Transport of oxygen in the blood
 Myoglobin   Storage of oxygen in muscle
 Cytochrome C   Involvement in the electron transport chain
 Cytochrome P450  Hydroxylation of xenobiotics
 Catalase  Degradation of hydrogen peroxide
 Tryptophan pyrrolase  Oxidation of tryptophan

questions.text: Which of the following statements about disaster management is incorrect?

choices.text: Rehabilitation is the final phase in a disaster that leads to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions.
Disaster mitigation is a risk reduction measure before the occurrence of a disaster.
Disaster preparedness is short-term developmental activity.
The response includes triage, tagging, identification of the dead, and relief activities.

questions.solution:
Disaster preparedness refers to long-term development activities to strengthen the capacity of a country to effectively manage all kinds of emergencies. 

Response - This includes activities such as:

Triage: Classifying the injured based on the severity of the injuries and chances of survival with medical intervention. 

Tagging: Tags with name, age, triage category, diagnosis, and treatment are put for identification purposes. 

Identification of the dead: The dead bodies should be shifted from the disaster site to the mortuary.

  • Rehabilitation - This includes measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control.
  • Mitigation - This includes measures to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of them are flood mitigation, land use planning, improved building codes, and the reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures. 
  • Preparedness - This is a program that aims at strengthening the capacity of a country to manage all types of emergencies efficiently. Its objective is to ensure that appropriate measurements are taken for the relief and rehabilitation of disaster victims.

Some measures that should be followed by all in case of an emergency include:

  • Avoiding telephone use, unless it is to call for help
  • Listen to and carry out the radio or loudspeaker broadcast messages
  • Carry out the official instructions given over the radio or by loudspeaker
  • Keep a family emergency kit ready

Note: Vaccination of the general population post-disaster against typhoid, cholera, and tetanus is not recommended by World Health Organization(WHO).

questions.text: A screening test was carried out among 114 people of which 15 had the disease. 22  people tested positive for the disease among which 14 had the disease. What is the sensitivity of the test?
questions.solution:
In this scenario:

  • The total number of subjects is 114
  • Of the 114 subjects, 15 had the disease( Total disease) 
  • 22 tested positive meaning total subjects with test positive
  • Only 14 of the 22 had disease meaning true positives. This leaves 8 subjects as false positives. 
  • Of the 15 who had disease, 14 tested positive implying only 1 subject was false negative. 

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

14 (TP)

8 (FP)

22

Test -

1 (FN)

91 (TN)

92

Total

15

99

114

Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100 = 14/(14+1)= 14/15

Thus, sensitivity is 93.3%.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following situations does the red line in the following graph depict?
questions.solution:
The Red line in the graph represents a reaction with Noncompetitive inhibitor. The above graph is called 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot.

1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained.This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

questions.text: Aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor is:
questions.solution:
Disulfiram is an irreversible inhibtor of both cytosolic and mitochondrial forms of aldehyde dehydrogenase.

Ethanol consumption during disulfiram therapy can lead to increased concentrations of acetaldehyde which causes flushing, pulsating headache, throbbing pain in head and neck, and other aversive reactions. It is indicated in alcohol deaddiction maintenance therapy in highly motivated patients.

Fomepizole is an inhibhitor of alcohol dehydrogenase (option A).

questions.text: A 19-year-old football player was brought to the hospital after he suffered an ​injury caused by a lateral blow to the knee joint. MRI revealed an injury to the ligaments commonly referred to as the 'unhappy triad'. Which of the following ligaments are involved?
questions.solution:
The ligaments involved in the unhappy triad of knee joint are structures 1 - Anterior cruciate ligament and 8 -Medial meniscus.

The unhappy triad of the knee involves medial meniscus, anterior cruciate ligament, and tibial collateral ligament.

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called as – O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triangle. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to lateral blow to the knee. It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

Image: Unhappy triad injury in MRI (after O'Donoghue) of the knee joint (PDW SPIR). Left to right: Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament, rupture of the medial collateral ligament, and inner meniscal tear (here complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
Phlycten is a white pinkish nodule surrounded by hyperemia on bulbar conjunctiva near limbus seen in phlyctenular conjunctivitis.

 Phlyctenular conjunctivitis 

  • Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction 
  • Due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Characterized by the following:
    • Phlycten
    • May eventually form ring ulcers
    • Scrofulous ulcer: shallow marginal ulcer due to the breakdown of limbal phlycten
    • Fascicular ulcer has a prominent parallel leash of blood vessels. It heals leaving a band-shaped opacity.

Treatment: Topical steroids; atropine if the cornea is involved.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient is brought to the casualty following an episode of seizure. He says he was recently switched to a higher dose of his antipsychotic medication.  Which drug is he most likely on?
questions.solution:
The drug most likely implicated here is clozapine as it has the highest risk of precipitating seizures. It causes dose-dependent lowering of the seizure threshold.

Clozapine-associated seizures can be treated with sodium valproate.

Clozapine side effects: (Mnemonic - “Some say Clozapine has too many nasty adverse effects”)

  • Seizures
  • Sedation
  • Constipation
  • Hypotension/hypersalivation
  • Tachycardia
  • Mass increase: weight gain and increased appetite
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Agranulocytosis (neutropenia)
  • Enuresis and polyuria

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination of the nose, she has roomy nasal cavities, foul-smelling discharge, and dry greenish crusts. She is also found to have merciful anosmia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of merciful anosmia, foul-smelling discharge, and roomy nasal cavities, with dry greenish crusts, points to a diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The exact etiology of this condition is not known. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. 

Clinically patients present with nasal obstruction, foul odor, and merciful anosmia. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

On examination of the nose, greenish or greyish crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, atrophied nasal turbinates, and epistaxis following the removal of the crusts. The roomy nasal cavity is seen due to the resorption of bones of the turbinates.

Treatment:

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, and sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, oestradiol, and vitamin D2. 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, and placental extract.
  • Surgical management:
    • Young's operation.
    • Modified young operation.
    • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

Other options:

Option B: Nasal polyps are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps. They present with a polypoid mass in the nose.

Option C: Allergic rhinitis is associated with inferior turbinate hypertrophy and can cause chronic nasal obstruction. It is characterized by watery nasal discharge, sneezing, and itching in the nose.

Option D: Foreign body nose is commonly seen in children. The child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

  • More common in females 
  • Usually starts at puberty
  • It is a bilateral condition
  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia)
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale

questions.text:
The SpO2 values of 5 patients in an ICU ward are given below. Which of the following statements is true?
SpO2 levels 90% 92% 92% 92% 94%
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, mean = median = mode.

The mean is the sum of all the elements divided by the number of elements in the distribution. In this scenario, the mean = (90 + 92 + 92 + 92 + 94) / 5 = 460/ 5= 92%

The median divides the frequency distribution in half when all the scores are listed in order. When a distribution has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value. When the distribution has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the two middle scores. In this scenario, the median = 92% which is the middle value.

The mode is the observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency. In this scenario, the mode = 92%

Hence, the mean = median = mode = 92%

In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same,  mean = median = mode. In a positively skewed distribution in which the long tail is towards the positive direction, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode. In a negatively skewed distribution in which the long tail is towards the negative direction, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Other options:

Option D: There is only one value that occurs with the greatest frequency. Hence, the frequency distribution is unimodal. If two values occur with the greatest frequency then the frequency distribution is bimodal. If more than two values occur with the greatest frequency then the distribution is multimodal.

questions.text: A placido disc test was performed on a patient. The result of the test is shown below. What is your interpretation?
questions.solution:
The test is Placido’s disc test, and the image shown is normal.

It is used to detect an abnormal corneal surface.

Irregularities of the cornea cause distortion of the circles

Distortion of the circle is seen in keratoconus, keratoglobus, corneal ulcer, and corneal abrasion.

Image: Placido's disc and different abnormalities.

questions.text:
Match the respective organisms with their periodicity.
1. Wuchereria bancrofti a. Diurnal
2. Loa loa b. Nocturnal
3. Onchocerca volvulus c. Nonperiodic
4.  Brugia malayi
questions.solution:
1. Wuchereria bancrofti b. Nocturnal 
2. Loa loa a. Diurnal
3. Onchocerca volvulus c. Nonperiodic
4.  Brugia malayi b. Nocturnal

The microfilariae are found in large numbers in the peripheral blood during specific times of the day, depending on the blood-feeding habits of their insect vector. This is known as periodicity. Filarial worms can exhibit nocturnal, diurnal periodicity, or no periodicity at all.

  • Nocturnal periodicity: When the largest number of microfilariae are present in the blood at night. Eg- Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, Brugia timori
  • Diurnal periodicity: When the largest number of microfilariae occur in blood during the day. Eg- Loa loa
  • Nonperiodic: When the number of microfilariae maintains a constant level during the day and night. Eg- Onchocerca volvulus
  • Subperiodic or nocturnally subperiodic: When the microfilariae can be detected in the blood throughout the day but are detected in larger numbers in the late afternoon or at night. Eg- Wuchereria bancrofti in the eastern Pacific and Brugia malayi in Indonesia and southeast Asia.

questions.text: A randomized control study was conducted on a group of 100 people to find out the causes and effects of different hormones that increase the secretion of insulin. All of the following factors increase its secretion except?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin decreases insulin secretion, whereas all others- acetylcholine, gastric inhibitory polypeptide, and arginine stimulate insulin secretion. 

Somatostatin, also known as growth hormone-inhibitory hormone, is secreted from delta cells of the islets of Langerhans. It acts locally from these cells to inhibit insulin and glucagon secretion. It decreases the utilization of the absorbed nutrients by the tissues. The main role of this hormone is to prevent rapid exhaustion of the food, thereby making it available over a longer period of time. 

Insulin is secreted by the pancreatic beta cells in response to increased blood glucose concentration. It promotes liver uptake, storage, and the utilization of glucose from the blood. If blood glucose levels are high, they cause glucose to be rapidly stored in the liver in the form of glycogen. It also promotes the conversion of this excess glucose to fatty acids. When glucose levels fall, insulin secretion is decreased and activation of enzyme phosphorylase split glycogen to release stored glucose into the circulating blood. 

Mechanism of insulin secretion:

Glucose enters beta cells of the pancreas via GLUT-2 receptors. Once inside, it is phosphorylated by glucokinase (rate-limiting step) to glucose-6-phosphate which is oxidized to form adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This ATP causes the closure of ATP-sensitive potassium channels and hence depolarization. This leads to opening voltage-gated calcium channels and Ca2+ influx. This stimulates the fusion of the insulin-containing vesicles with the cell membrane and the secretion of insulin into the extracellular fluid by exocytosis.

questions.text: Vasodilator of the inner ear is _____.
questions.solution:
Betahistine is a vasodilator of the inner ear. It is used in the treatment of Meniere's disease.

It is reported to act by:

  • Improving microvascular circulation in the stria vascularis of the cochlea.
  • Inhibiting vestibular nuclei activity.

Note: The answer has been revised to betahistine from nicotinic acid, to reflect new updates in the reference.

questions.text: You are a medical officer in an Urban Health and Wellness Center (UHWC). The population of the place is 10,000. How many ASHA workers are needed for your UHWC?
questions.solution:
In a place with a population of 10,000, 5 ASHA workers are needed. 

There are two forms of Health and Wellness Centers in Sub-Health Centers.

  • Health and Wellness Centre - Sub-Health Center (HWC-SHC) in rural areas: It requires 1 ASHA per 1000 population or 1 ASHA per habitation in hilly/tribal areas. It has a total staff of 3 + ASHAs.
  • Urban Health and Wellness Center (UHWC): It requires 1 ASHA per 2000 population and 1 ANM per 10000 population. Health and wellness center- Sub-Center 1 ASHA per 1,000 population or 1 ASHA per habitation in hilly/tribal areas. It has a total staff of 4 + ASHAs.

Functions of HWCs under Sub-Health Centers:

  • Provide primary care services
  • Deliver the 12 packages under CPHC
  • Serve as a platform for teleconsultation and widening the range of diagnostics
  • Serve as a fulcrum for services in National Health Programmes

ASHA is an Accredited Social Health Activist.

An ASHA must be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old and have a formal education till 10th standard preferably if they are in good numbers. This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She is part of the primary health care at the village level.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements.

    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

questions.text: A 25-year-old farmer was admitted with acute onset of fever, cough, and dyspnea. Chest radiograph showed pneumonia-like findings, for which he was treated. After 1 month he again presented with similar symptoms and progressive dyspnea. CT chest showed diffuse ground glass changes. Which of the following is a causative agent for a given disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a farmer with recurrent attacks of pneumonia-like symptoms is suggestive of farmer's lung. The causative agent associated with the condition is thermophilic actinomycetes.

Farmer's lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by exposure to moldy hay containing spores of thermophilic actinomycetes fungus like Saccharopolyspora rectivirgula.

A patient with acute farmer’s lung presents 4–8 h after exposure with fever, chills, malaise, cough, and dyspnea. It occurs due to inhalation of moldy hay and grains causing an immunological reaction. A history of exposure to antigens is essential to distinguish this disease from influenza or pneumonia with similar symptoms.

In the chronic form of the disease, the history of repeated attacks after similar exposure can be present. Repeated attacks can lead to pulmonary fibrosis and cor pulmonale.

A wide variety of other organic dust is associated with the occurrence of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis, also known as extrinsic allergic alveolitis, is an inflammatory response to various inhaled antigens. A history of exposure to the offending antigen is present. Chest x-ray findings are nonspecific and can show ground-glass opacities or ill-defined micronodular opacities.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the bradycardia seen in Cushing reflex?
questions.solution:
The bradycardia seen in the Cushing reflex is caused by baroreceptor activation in response to a raised arterial blood pressure.

The Cushing reflex is a triad of raised arterial blood pressure, bradycardia, and irregular respiration caused by raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Raised ICP compromises blood flow to the brain and activates the rostral ventrolateral medulla with an increase in arterial blood pressure. The increased arterial pressure maintains cerebral perfusion and activates the baroreceptor reflex that causes bradycardia.

The irregular respiration seen in the Cushing reflex is caused by inadequate blood flow and increased pressure on the brainstem.

Bainbridge reflex: It refers to the increase in the heart rate when the atrium is stretched. Whenever there is a stretch of the atrium, the stretch receptors are activated. They transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase the heart rate and strength of heart contraction. This reflex prevents the accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and pulmonary circulation.

J reflex: C fiber-endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension. 

Bezold Jarisch reflex (Coronary chemoreflex): Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region (eg, juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This is called the Bezold Jarisch reflex and can be elicited by capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography.

questions.text: A child was brought to the primary health center for vaccination. The parents informed the medical officer that the child had a history of egg allergy. Which of the following vaccines can not be given to the child?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, yellow fever cannot be given to a child who has an egg allergy.

Yellow fever and influenza vaccines are prepared in hen's egg tissues. Hence, they cannot be given to a patient with a history of anaphylactic reactions following egg ingestion. However, vaccine viruses propagated in chicken fibroblast cells like measles or MMR vaccines can be given.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with heartburn and increased salivation. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGE) was done, and the biopsy result is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histological image above shows the transition between normal squamous epithelium and the mucin-filled glands, indicating intestinal-type metaplasia with plenty of goblet cells which is suggestive of Barrett’s esophagus.

Barrett’s esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa. It is a premalignant condition that confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Hence, patients diagnosed with Barrett’s Esophagus must be subjected to a regular surveillance endoscopy annually or at 2-year intervals, provided no dysplasias have been detected. The presence of dysplasia is associated with prolonged symptoms, longer segment length, increased patient age, and Caucasian race.

It is a premalignant condition that confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A newly pregnant woman from a rural area registered in the scheme shown below. Which of the following benefits would she receive under this scheme?

choices.text: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 homebased newborn care visits
Free checkup on 9th of every month

questions.solution:
The above image shows the logo of Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA). Under this scheme, all pregnant women will receive a free checkup on the 9th of every month.

Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA):

Benefit: Free checkup on the 9th of every month.

Objective: Improve the quality and coverage of antenatal care, diagnostics, and counseling services.

Implementation: Pregnant women receive at least one check-up in their second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, specifically on the 9th of every month.

After routine examination, pregnant women are categorized according to the risk factors, and different coloured stickers are pasted on mother and child protection cards.

  • Green sticker: For women with no detected risk factor
  • Red sticker: For women with detected risk factor

Other options:

Option A: Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (PMMVY):

  • Benefit: Cash incentive of 5000 rupees.
  • Eligibility: Provided to all pregnant women and lactating mothers for the first living child of the
  • family, subject to specific conditions.

Option B: Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN):

  • Benefit: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 home-based newborn care visits.
  • Objective: Assured, dignified, and respectful delivery of quality healthcare services at no cost, aiming to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths.
  • Implementation: Ensures zero tolerance for denial of services to any woman and newborn, providing antenatal checkups and home-based newborn care visits.

Option D: Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY):

  • Benefit: Cash incentive of 1400 rupees.
  • Eligibility: Provided to all pregnant women who undergo institutional delivery in low-performing states.
  • Objective: Promote institutional delivery to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality.
