questions.text: A 30-year old patient comes to the hospital with complaints of blood-tinged nasal discharge. The anterior rhinoscopy shows a pink polypoidal mass in the right nose and the same is biopsied. The image given below is the histological slide of the specimen. Treatment of choice for this condition is?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathology showing several sporangia is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis. Surgical management (Excision of the lesion with cauterisation of the base ), is the treatment of choice in rhinosporidiosis.

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Patients clinically present with blood-tinged nasal discharge, and pink polypoidal mass in the nose.

Histopathology shows several sporangia, oval, or round in shape and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its chitinous wall.

It is treated by completely excising the mass with a diathermy knife followed by cauterization of the base.

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with difficulty breathing and cyanosis after being exposed to phosphine gas in a garage while repairing a vehicle. Despite receiving 100% oxygen, his oxygen saturation remains low and does not improve. What type of hypoxia is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Phosphine causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting mitochondrial function and disrupting cellular respiration at the tissue level.

Phosphine causes histotoxic hypoxia, and thus, by preventing the O2 utilization at the tissue level, it acts as a powerful stimulus for peripheral chemoreceptors. Phosphine inhibits cytochrome oxidase (Complex IV) in the electron transport chain. This disrupts oxidative phosphorylation, preventing ATP production despite adequate oxygen availability.

In phosphine poisoning the oxygen is present but cells cannot use it due to blocked cellular respiration. This is why simple oxygen supplementation isn't effective as a primary treatment.

Other options:

Option B: Anemic hypoxia occurs due to decreased hemoglobin in the blood capable of carrying oxygen. This can be in the form of a low amount of hemoglobin, defective hemoglobin, or interference with hemoglobin-oxygen binding. Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning is classified as anemic hypoxia as CO preferentially binds to hemoglobin and reduces the oxygen binding. Treatment involves terminating the exposure to CO and oxygen supplementation.

Option C: Hypoxic hypoxia refers to a reduced partial pressure of oxygen in the arterial blood. It has multiple causes, like high altitude, hypoventilation, right-to-left shunts, diffusion defects, and ventilation-perfusion mismatch. Chronic emphysema is an example of hypoxic hypoxia, as there is alveolar destruction leading to reduced gas exchange and ventilation-perfusion mismatch. In most cases, supplemental oxygen is helpful in treatment.

Option D: Stagnant hypoxia refers to ischemic hypoxia that results from inadequate circulation due to conditions such as heart failure and hypoxia in the setting of shock. In such conditions, administering intravenous fluids can improve the patient's condition because it is the circulation that is affected. If the shock is prolonged it can result in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which can be treated with positive pressure ventilation and not simply by increasing oxygen administration.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is derived from the right 4th aortic arch?
questions.solution:
The proximal part of the right subclavian artery is derived from the right 4th aortic arch. 

The distal segment of the right subclavian artery is derived from the right dorsal aorta and the 7th intersegmental artery.

questions.text: Which of the following does not act by increasing insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
The drug that does not act by increasing insulin secretion is rosiglitazone.

Rosiglitazone is a thiazolidinedione, which activates PPAR-γ receptors in adipose tissue and skeletal muscles. These are insulin sensitizers and increase insulin-mediated glucose uptake in patients with type 2 diabetes. These also reduce hepatic glucose production and increase glucose uptake.

The most common adverse effects of thiazolidinediones are weight gain, fluid retention, and edema.

Other options:

Option A - Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) analog that increases insulin secretion by stimulating the pancreas. 

Option C - Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP) inhibitor. It prevents the degradation of GLP by inhibiting DPP-4. GLP-1 is an incretin that is rapidly inactivated by dipeptidyl peptidase. So, inhibition of dipeptidyl peptidase enhances the action of incretins and facilitates insulin release.

Option D - Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that also stimulates insulin secretion. They bind to a specific site on the β cell K-ATP channel complex and inhibit its activity. This causes cell membrane to depolarize and leads to cascade of events resulting in insulin secretion.

questions.text: An elderly patient with ventricular tachycardia has been started on amiodarone. Which of the following is the most important adverse event associated with this drug's use?
questions.solution:
The most important adverse event associated with the use of amiodarone is pulmonary fibrosis. 

Amiodarone is a class three anti-arrhythmic that is primarily used in the treatment of supraventricular arrhythmias, ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Pulmonary fibrosis is usually seen in patients who take prolonged courses of amiodarone and in high doses.

Pulmonary fibrosis can be potentially life-threatening and requires immediate discontinuation of the amiodarone and initiation of high-dose corticosteroids.

Other adverse events associated with amiodarone use are nausea, photosensitivity, corneal microdeposits and thyroid dysfunction.

Other options:

Option B: Central nervous system toxicity. There are no significant central nervous system-related adverse events. In a minority of patients, peripheral neuropathy presenting as shoulder and pelvic muscle weakness is seen.

Option C: Renal dysfunction is not seen with Amiodarone since it is hepatically cleared.

Option D: Ototoxicity is associated with prolonged aminoglycoside use and is not a feature of amiodarone toxicity.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with recurrent attacks of tonsillitis and speech difficulties was posted for a tonsillectomy procedure. Which of the following position is used in this surgery?
questions.solution:
Rose position is used in tonsillectomy surgery. 

In Rose's position, the patient is supine, with their head extended. A rubber ring is placed under the head to stabilize it and a pillow is placed under the shoulders to extend the head. Rose's position is also used in adenoidectomy and tracheostomy.

 

Indications of tonsillectomy are:

  • Recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis – most common indication
  • Febrile seizures due to fever in tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) - recurrent episodes in adults and a single episode in children
  • Hypertrophy of tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in deglutition, interference with speech
  • Unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspicion of malignancy
  • Chronic tonsillitis with bad taste or halitosis which is unresponsive to medical treatment (relative indication)
  • As a part of the surgical management of sleep apnea syndrome, glossopharyngeal neuralgia, and Eagle's syndrome.

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

  • Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Presence of acute infection in upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis. Bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia or haemophilia.
  • At the time of the epidemic of polio.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

Other options:

Option A: The sniffing position involves flexion of the neck on the body and extension of the head on the neck which is done during tracheal intubation.

Option B: Semi fowler position is lying supine incline at an angle of 30 - 45 degrees. This position is used for patients who have cardiac or respiratory conditions, and for patients with a nasogastric tube. 

Option C: Reverse Trendelenburg position is lying flat with head 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. This position is used in ocular and ENT surgeries like minimally invasive cataract surgery and rhinoplasty.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the vector shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The vector shown in the image is a hard tick that transmits Ehrlichia, Babesiosis and Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF). Scrub typhus (Orientia) caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi is transmitted by trombiculid mites.

A hard tick has an oval-shaped body, no antennae with 4 pairs of legs and is covered by a chitinous shield on its dorsal surface(scutum). It transmits diseases such as Ehrlichia, babesiosis, viral hemorrhagic fevers like Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) and Kyasanur forest disease (KFD), tick typhus, viral encephalitis (e.g., Russian spring-summer encephalitis), viral fevers (e.g., Colorado tick fever), tularemia, tick paralysis.

The following image shows a soft tick.

Scrub typhus is transmitted by a trombiculid mite which is as shown below.

questions.text: The most common translocation in gastric MALToma is_____.
questions.solution:
The most common translocation in gastric MALToma is t(11;18)(q21;q21).

Three translocations are associated with gastric MALToma:

  1. t(11;18)(q21;q21) - Most common
  2. t(1;14)(p22;q32)
  3. t(14;18)(q32;q21).

questions.text: Identify the given condition:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic dendritic ulcers seen in herpes simplex keratitis.

Herpes simplex keratitis is caused by the Herpes simplex virus (HSV). The patient complains of ocular discomfort, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity. HSV can cause characteristic epithelial (dendritic/geographic) keratitis or disciform keratitis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man came to the OPD with blurred vision. His fundus examination was done. The fundus appearance is as shown in the image given below. This appearance is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Bayoneting sign is an advanced glaucomatous change in the optic disc.

Sharp angulation of vessels is seen at the margin of the excavated cup.

Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc

Early glaucomatous changes

  • Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Splinter hemorrhages on disc margin
  • Large cup: 0.7 or more
  • Asymmetry of the cups: A difference equal to or more than 0.2 between two eyes is significant
  • Vertically oval cup

Advanced glaucomatous changes

  • Marked cupping (Beanpot cupping)
  • Thinning of neuroretinal rim
  • Bayoneting sign: Sharp angulation of vessel at margin of excavated cup
  • Laminar dot sign

questions.text: Which of the following is an intracellular pathogen?
questions.solution:
Brucella is primarily an intracellular pathogen affecting reticuloendothelial system. This accounts for its refractoriness to chemotherapy. 

Brucella species are Gram-negative, facultative intracellular bacteria that cause brucellosis, a zoonotic infection transmitted from animals to humans. Brucella organisms are capable of surviving and replicating within phagocytes (such as macrophages) after being engulfed by these cells. Once inside the phagocytes, Brucella can evade the host immune response and establish chronic infections.

Other options:

Option B: Haemophilus influenzae is a Gram-negative bacterium that can cause a variety of infections, including pneumonia, meningitis, and otitis media. While it can be associated with respiratory tract infections, it is primarily an extracellular pathogen, meaning it typically resides and replicates outside of host cells.

Option C: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a Gram-negative bacterium that is known for causing opportunistic infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals or those with cystic fibrosis. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is mainly an extracellular pathogen, although it can invade and survive within certain host cells in specific conditions.

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is ___
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of breathing difficulty and unsuccessful attempts of extubation after total thyroidectomy is suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury is often acute. Neuritis or surgical trauma (thyroidectomy) are the most important causes. All the intrinsic muscles are paralyzed in this condition. The vocal cords lie in the median or paramedian position due to the unopposed action of cricothyroid muscles. This leads to dyspnoea and stridor but the voice is good.

Tracheostomy is done as an emergency procedure. Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:

  • Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation) - it involves excising laterally the soft tissue at the junction of membranous cord and vocal process of arytenoid with laser.
  • Partial arytenoidectomy - it involves excision of the medial part of the arytenoid with laser.
  • Reinnervation procedures - these are used to innervate paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.
  • Thyroplasty type II - it creates lateral expansion of larynx.

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient presents with a white corrugated plaque on the lateral border of the tongue that cannot be rubbed off. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an immunocompromised patient presenting with a white corrugated plaque on the lateral border of the tongue that cannot be rubbed off is suggestive of oral hairy leukoplakia caused by Epstein Barr Virus (EBV).

Hairy leukoplakia is a distinct oral lesion on the lateral border of the tongue caused by EBV that typically occurs in immunocompromised patients. It appears as white, confluent patches of fluffy or hairy, hyperkeratotic thickenings, almost always on the lateral border of the tongue. Unlike Candida-caused oral thrush, the lesion cannot be rubbed away.

Predisposing factors include Immunodeficiency, haematological malignancies, and steroid abuse.

The Epstein-Barr virus replicates in maturing epithelial cells but not in basal or parabasal keratinocytes. On microscopy, the upper spinous layer shows the characteristic hyperparakeratosis and acanthosis with balloon cells.

Investigations show high levels of EBV DNA in the blood with circulating antibodies against viral capsid antigen (VCA) and early antigen (EA)‐restricted proteins.

Other options:

Option A: Oral Thrush/ oral candidiasis associated with Candida albicans presents as white plaque-like lesions with cheesy exudate on an erythematous mucosa. They are typically painful and can be easily brushed off. 

Option B: AIDS-associated Kaposi sarcoma (KS) due to human herpes virus-8 (HHV-8) is an AIDS-defining illness and is the most common malignancy associated with HIV infection. Kaposi sarcoma mainly affects the hard‐palate mucosa in particular. The gingiva, tongue and buccal mucosa are also involved. The initial lesion is a reddish-purple macule, which develops into a purple nodule swelling that could be widespread and ulcerated.

Option C: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection is common in and around the mouth. HSV-1 is the primary cause of gingivostomatitis, which is most common in children. The gums are swollen, inflamed and bleed easily. The mucous membranes of the tongue, pharynx, palate, and buccal region are covered in vesicles that appear as white plaques. The plaques turn into ulcers with a pseudomembrane that is yellow in colour. The regional lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the maintenance of opioid dependence as a substitute therapy?
questions.solution:
Methadone is used for the maintenance of opioid (heroin) dependence as a substitute therapy because of its good oral bioavailability and long half-life. 

Methadone is substituted for opioids during detoxification to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Once stabilized, the dose is gradually reduced and the drug is stopped slowly over days.

Treatment for opioid dependence - 

Maintainance phase: to decrease the severity of withdrawal symptoms.

  • Long-acting opioid agonist: methadone is given to prevent the withdrawal symptoms.
  • Partial agonist: buprenorphine can also be used.
  • Clonidine, lofexidine: alpha-2 agonist acts as sympatholytic and reduces the withdrawal symptoms.

Relapse prevention phase:

  • Naltrexone: an opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)?
questions.solution:
Pour plate culture (quantitative test) is not used as an immediate test for screening of UTI. However it is considered the best diagnostic test for confirmation of UTI due it’s high sensitivity and specificity.

The screening tests for UTI are as follows:

  • Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine. 
  • Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine.
  • Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result.
  • Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.

Quantitative Culture:

  • Standardized loop technique
  • Pour plate method

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presented with sudden, progressive, painless loss of vision in the right eye. There was no history of associated photopsia. On examination, shifting fluid sign is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the presence of shifting fluid is suggestive of exudative retinal detachment (ED). 

Exudative RD is characterized by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina in the absence of a retinal break or traction. Fluid leaks outside the vessels and accumulates under the retina. RD does not occur as long as the retinal pigment epithelium is pumping the leaking fluid into the choroidal circulation. 

Causes:

  • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
  • Choroidal tumors like melanoma
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Coats disease

Patients may present with painless progressive visual field defects without photopsia. Floaters may be present if there is an associated vitritis.

Clinical signs include

  • Convex configuration of the retinal detachment, with a smooth surface
  • A detached retina is very mobile
  • Shifting fluid sign - Subretinal fluid causes detachment of the retinal portion under which it accumulates. In the upright position, the fluid collects under the inferior retina. But in the supine position, the inferior retina flattens and the fluid shifts posteriorly, which leads to detachment of the superior retina.
  • The cause of the RD may be apparent. 
  • Leopard spots - Scattered areas of clumped subretinal pigment may be seen after the detachment has flattened.

Retinal detachment (RD) is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. It is classified into the following:

  • Rhegmatogenous RD - due to a tear or break in the retina
  • Secondary RD - due to some other preceding event
    • Exudative RD
    • Tractional RD

The image shows the shifting fluid sign and late-phase fluorescein angiogram showing hyperfluorescent spots with a leopard spot pattern in the posterior fundus and staining of the arteries and an avascular area in the nasal region, respectively.

Other options:

Option A: Breaks in the Descemet membrane may occur due to

  • Corneal enlargement in infantile glaucoma. Haab striae are horizontal concentric lines representing the breaks in Descemet’s membrane, seen in patients with congenital glaucoma.
  • Deformations such as keratoconus
  • Birth trauma

The image below shows Haab's striae. 

Option B -  Rhegmatogenous RD: In this condition, fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina. The most dangerous type of retinal break is a horseshoe tear. The most dangerous location of the retinal break is the superior temporal retina. Risk factors for the development of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • High myopia
  • Blunt trauma
  • Previous cataract surgery (aphakia and pseudophakia)
  • Lattice degeneration of the retina

Clinical features of rhegmatogenous RD:

  • Symptoms
    • Photopsia: Flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break. Photopsia is symptom-specific for rhegmatogenous detachment. 
    • Floaters: Due to associated vitreous hemorrhage
    • Visual field defect: A black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Shaffer's sign: Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) is a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in its configuration.
    • The surface is corrugated with undulations.

 

Option C - Tractional RD: It occurs when the vitreous has an abnormally strong attachment to the retina. With vitreous liquefaction and subsequent contraction, the retina is pulled away from the retinal pigment epithelium without a retinal break.

  • Causes
    • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
    • Retinopathy of prematurity
    • Eales' disease
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is concave in its configuration.
    • No breaks are seen.

The image below shows the tractional segments and bands with a concave retina.

questions.text: Interstitial fluid volume is best measured using a combination of which two dyes?
questions.solution:
Interstitial fluid volume is best measured using a combination of inulin and Evans blue.

Inulin is a marker that distributes uniformly throughout the extracellular fluid, including the interstitial fluid, while Evans blue remains confined to the intravascular space. By using both dyes, one can measure the total extracellular fluid volume with inulin and the intravascular volume with Evans blue, allowing for the calculation of interstitial fluid volume.

Insterstitial fluid is measured indirectly. Interstitial fluid volume= ECF - plasma volume.

  • Best measure of ECF: Inulin
  • Best measure of Plasma Volume: Evans Blue (T1824)

  • Sodium thiosulphate
  • Sodium thiocyanate

questions.text: Which of the following will increase the GFR?

choices.text: Decrease in bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.solution:
A decrease in Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure causes an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

A decrease in Bowman's Capsule Hydrostatic Pressure increases GFR because it reduces the opposing force to filtration, thus enhancing the net filtration pressure and increasing the amount of filtrate formed.

Factors that can increase the GFR are as follows:

  • Increase in glomerular capillary filtration coefficient Kf: This coefficient depends on the hydraulic conductivity and surface area of the glomerular capillaries. 
  • Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Conditions with urinary tract obstruction can lead to an increase in this pressure and a fall in GFR.
  • Decrease in glomerular colloid osmotic pressure: Accumulation of plasma proteins that are not filtered from the blood contributes to this pressure, and an increase reduces further filtration and GFR. It is directly proportional to the following factors: Arterial plasma colloid osmotic pressure.
  • Filtration fraction : An increase in filtration fraction concentrates the plasma proteins and raises the glomerular colloid osmotic pressure which in turn decreases the GFR.

Other options : 

Option A: Efferent Arteriole Dilation reduces the resistance to blood leaving the glomerulus. This leads to a decrease in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure. A reduction in hydrostatic pressure lowers the driving force for filtration, resulting in a decreased GFR.

Option B: Afferent Arteriole Constriction decreases blood flow into the glomerulus. This lowers the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure. Lower pressure reduces the filtration rate across the glomerular capillary wall, leading to a decrease in GFR.

Option C: Increase in Glomerular Plasma Flow: If glomerular plasma flow increases but the efferent arteriole doesn't constrict, the extra blood flow is quickly carried away. This prevents a significant rise in the pressure inside the glomerular capillaries. As a result, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) doesn't significantly increase, because the necessary increase in filtration pressure doesn't occur.

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting GFR

↓Kf (filtration coefficient)→ ↓GFR

Renal disease, diabetes mellitus, hypertension

↑PB → ↓GFR

Urinary tract obstruction (e.g., kidney stones)

↑πG → ↓GFR

↓ Renal blood flow increased plasma proteins

↓PG → ↓GFR

a) ↑afferent arteriolar resistance (RA )→ ↓PG

↑ Sympathetic activity, (e.g., norepinephrine, endothelin)

b) ↓systemic arterial pressure(AP )→ ↓PG

↓ Angiotensin II (drugs that block angiotensin II formation)

questions.text: Gold standard investigation before Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) is?
questions.solution:
The gold standard investigation before FESS is a CT scan to rule out other pathologies and for confirmation of diagnosis. CT scan is better than MRI for visualizing bones and their anatomy.

Even while doing surgery, decisions on whether to open the mastoid antrum are based on CT findings and intraoperative findings. FESS is done for failed medical management of rhinosinusitis.

Other indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis that is unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis (diffuse nasal polyposis)
  • Fungal sinusitis with a fungal ball or nasal polypi
  • Antrochoanal polyp
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus
  • Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus
  • Endoscopic septoplasty

Advanced nasal endoscopic techniques

  • Removal of benign tumors, e.g. inverted papillomas or angiofibromas.
  • Orbital abscess or cellulitis management.
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy
  • Repair of CSF leak
  • Pituitary surgery
  • Optic nerve decompression
  • Orbital decompression for Graves’ disease
  • Control of posterior epistaxis (endoscopic clipping of sphenopalatine artery)
  • Choanal atresia.

questions.text: Malate shuttle is important in _______.
questions.solution:
Malate shuttle is important in both, gluconeogenesis and glycolysis.

Malate shuttle is a biochemical system for translocating impermeable electrons (NADH) or substrates (oxaloacetate), in the form of a permeable substance, malate. The semipermeable inner mitochondrial membrane is permeable to malate.

In glycolysis, the impermeable NADH produced in the cytosol (of liver and cardiac cells) are taken up into mitochondria for oxidation via malate shuttle.

In gluconeogenesis, pyruvate in the mitochondria yields impermeable oxaloacetate, which is converted to aspartate and translocated to the cytosol via malate shuttle for the synthesis of glucose.

questions.text: An elderly male patient was brought to the casualty. He has a history of progressive weakness on the right side of the body except for the leg. CT scan is shown below. Which vessel is likely to be thrombosed?
questions.solution:
The middle cerebral artery is likely to be thrombosed. A lesion in the middle cerebral artery causes contralateral hemiparesis, sparing the leg area. 

Anterior cerebral artery:
  • It is the smaller terminal branch of the internal carotid artery.
  • It runs in the sagittal fissure and anastomoses with the posterior cerebral artery.
  • It supplies the medial surface of the cerebral cortex and parts of lentiform, caudate nuclei, and the internal capsule.
 
Middle cerebral artery:
  • It is the larger terminal branch of the internal carotid artery.
  • It runs in the lateral sulcus.
  • It supplies the entire lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere except for a narrow strip (supplied by the anterior cerebral artery) and the occipital pole and the inferolateral surface (supplied by the posterior cerebral artery).  
Posterior cerebral artery:
  • It is the terminal branch of the basilar artery.
  • It supplies the occipital lobe, inferolateral and medial surfaces of the temporal lobe, and parts of the brainstem.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with endometrial carcinoma. Her family history reveals that her mother died of endometrial cancer at the age of 50 years, while her 42-year-old brother was recently diagnosed with a familial colon cancer. Which of the following genes is most likely to be mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above characteristic clinical and family history is suggestive of hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) syndrome, or Lynch syndrome, caused by mutations in the MSH2 gene.

Lynch syndrome is due to defects in DNA mismatch repair genes, with MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2.

HNPCC shows familial clustering of cancers at several sites, including the colorectum, endometrium, stomach, ovary, ureters, brain, small bowel, hepatobiliary tract, pancreas, and skin.

Gynecologic malignancies (usually endometrial, ovarian tumors) are often diagnosed before colorectal tumors in female patients with HNPCC.

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before age 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops fever, oliguria, periorbital edema and smoky cola-colored urine  2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. His renal biopsy image is given below. The most likely diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical details and histological image given, the most likely diagnosis is nephritic syndrome, occurring as a consequence of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

The PSGN patient presents with hematuria, red cell casts in the urine, azotemia, oliguria, hypertension, mild to moderate proteinuria, and edema (features of nephritic syndrome)

The classic histologic picture is of enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with influx of leucocytes (endocapillary proliferation).

questions.text: Which among the following is the most precise method of estimation of burn surface area?
questions.solution:
The Lund-Browder burn diagram is the more precise method of estimation of burn surface area.

Estimation of burn surface area.

  • Rule of nines (Wallace) - It divides the body into segments that are approximately 9% or multiples of 9%, with the perineum forming the remaining 1%. Because of the proportionately larger heads and smaller legs of infants and children, this method must be modified in pediatric burn injury.

NOTE: Lund and Browder method of estimation of burn area is the most accurate method in children and overall.

  • Use of patient's hand - The area of the back of the patient’s hand is approximately 1% of their total body surface area. The number of “hands” that equal the area of the burn can approximate the percentage of body surface area burned.
  • Lund-Browder burn diagram - This allows an accurate age-adjusted determination of burn size for a given depth, allowing for the anatomical differences of children.

questions.text: Internal architecture of the liver is divided into Couinaud's segments based on the distribution of ________
questions.solution:
Couinaud's segments are based on distribution of hepatic portal vein.

Veins of the liver:

  • Hepatic portal vein
    • It collects the blood from gall bladder, pancreas, and spleen and abdominal part of the alimentary tract.
    • It transfers the blood collected from these organs to the liver.
  • Hepatic vein
    • It is the vein of the liver which collects the de-oxygenated blood from the liver.
    • It directly drains into the inferior vena cava and ultimately into the heart.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's Liver Segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

questions.text: Transport molecule for Fe2+ into the enterocytes is
questions.solution:
Iron is brought into the cell through an active transport process with the help of Divalent Metal Transporter 1(DMT-1)

Protein DMT-1 (Divalent Metal Transporter-1)

  • Expressed on the apical surface of enterocytes in initial part of duodenum.
  • DMT-1 is not specific to iron & transports other substances like zinc, copper, cobalt & manganese

questions.text: On observing the presence of Fleischer vortex(whorl keratopathy) during the ocular examination of a patient, you would expect to find a history of intake of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Chloroquine, an anti-malarial drug may get deposited in the cornea leading to whorl-like opacity in corneal epithelium called cornea verticillata/vortex keratopathy/ Fleisher vortex/ whorl keratopathy.

Long-term treatment with chloroquine may sometimes cause whorl-like opacity in corneal epithelium called cornea verticillata.

Other causes of corneal verticillata: 

  • Fabry’s disease
  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Indomethacin
  • Phenothiazines
  • Atovaquone

Other side effects of Chloroquine are:

  • Gastrointestinal (common): Abdominal cramps, anorexia, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting
  • Cardiovascular: Atrioventricular block, bundle branch block, cardiac arrhythmia, cardiac failure, cardiomyopathy, ECG changes, hypotension, torsades de pointes, ventricular fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia
  • Dermatologic: Alopecia, bleaching of hair, blue-grey skin pigmentation, erythema multiforme, exacerbation of psoriasis, urticaria, etc
  • Endocrine & metabolic: Exacerbation of porphyria, severe hypoglycemia
  • Hematologic & oncologic: Agranulocytosis (reversible), aplastic anemia, hemolytic anemia (in G6PD-deficient patients), neutropenia, pancytopenia, thrombocytopenia
  • Hepatic: Hepatitis, increased liver enzymes
  • Nervous system: Agitation, anxiety, confusion, decreased deep tendon reflex, delirium, depression, extrapyramidal reaction (dystonia, dyskinesia, protrusion of the tongue, torticollis) etc
  • Neuromuscular & skeletal: Asthenia, myopathy, neuromuscular disease, proximal myopathy
  • Ophthalmic: Accommodation disturbances, blurred vision, corneal opacity (reversible), macular degeneration (may be irreversible), maculopathy (may be irreversible), night blindness, retinal pigment changes (bull’s eye appearance), retinopathy (including irreversible changes in long-term or high-dose therapy), transient scotomata, visual field defect (paracentral scotomas)
A bilateral whorl-like corneal pattern of cream-colored lines, as shown in the image below, is called corneal verticillata.

Image below shows increased fluorescence in the macular area and round-shaped blocked fluorescence in the central fovea. It is likely due chloroquine toxicity.

Other options:

  • Commonly seen side effects with leflunomide are headache, alopecia, skin rash, diarrhea and nausea.

  • Commonly seen side effects with primaquine are gastrointestinal, cardiac arrhythmia, dizziness, pruritus, skin rash, anemia, hemolytic anemia (in patients with G6PD deficiency), leukopenia and methemoglobinemia (in NADH-methemoglobin reductase-deficient individuals)

  • Commonly seen side effects with apraclonidine are gastrointestinal, xerostomia, eye discomfort, eye pruritus and ocular hyperemia.

questions.text: What is the location of the complexes shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows the electron transport chain (ETC) which is located on the inner mitochondrial membrane. 

The electron transport chain (ETC) is a specialized set of electron carriers that can accept electrons. Energy-rich molecules like glucose are oxidized to produce water and carbon dioxide. The intermediate substrates in these reactions can pass on electrons to certain coenzymes like nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2).

The energy from electron transfer is used to move H+ through the inner mitochondrial membrane. The H+ gradient thus produced results in the production of ATP. ATP synthesis together with electron transport is known as oxidative phosphorylation. 

Option B - Outer mitochondrial membrane has acyl-CoA synthetase and glycerol phosphate acyltransferase.

Option C - Mitochondrial matrix has citric acid cycle enzymes, β-oxidation enzymes, and pyruvate dehydrogenase.

Option D - Intermembrane space has adenylyl kinase and creatine kinase. It is filled with H+ creating a proton gradient. 

 The reactions in oxidative phosphorylation and the arrangement of complexes that form the ETC are shown below.

questions.text: A boy with a history of a fall from a tree presents with a lurching gait and dragging of his feet. Which of the following structures are involved?
questions.solution:
The structure responsible for lurching gait in the child is gluteus medius represented by 2.

The gluteus medius originates from the outer surface of the ileum between the anterior and posterior gluteal lines. Insertion of the muscle is at the lateral surface of the greater trochanter. It is supplied by the superior gluteal nerve.

Gluteus medius and minimus are powerful abductors of the hip joint. Mechanism of actions of gluteus medius and minimus:

  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in a slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • The actions of these muscles are affected when there is an injury to the superior gluteal nerve, neck of the femur, or loss of normal angulation of the shaft of the femur. This occurs in conditions like paralysis of the glutei, developmental dysplasia of the hip, etc.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb. This leads to a positive Trendelenburg's sign with a characteristic lurching gait - the patient lurches towards the affected side with contralateral pelvis drop. 

Other options

1 - Gluteus maximus - involved in the extension of flexed thigh, abduction (only upper fibres), and lateral rotation at the hip joint. Insertion is at the iliotibial tract. 

3 - Piriformis - involved in lateral rotation and assists abduction at the hip joint. It is inserted into the medial side of greater trochanter of the femur. Entrapment of the sciatic nerve in the piriformis can lead to piriformis syndrome.

4 - Sciatic nerve - The nerve passes over the obturator internus, gemellus superior, gemellus inferior and quadratus femoris. It supplies knee flexors and muscles below the knee. Paralysis of this nerve results in flail foot and severe difficulty in walking.

questions.text: A patient was incidentally found to have essential fructosuria. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Essential fructosuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme hepatic fructokinase, inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Fructokinase is the first enzyme to act on fructose metabolism.

  • This defective degradation does not cause any clinical symptoms.
  • Fructose is either excreted unchanged in the urine or metabolized to fructose-6-phosphate by alternate pathways in the body, most commonly by hexokinase in adipose tissue and muscle.
  • No treatment is indicated for essential fructosuria.

Other options:

Aldolase A is an enzyme involved in glycolysis, catalyzing the conversion of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate to glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and dihydroxyacetone phosphate. It is not directly related to fructose metabolism, so it is not deficient in essential fructosuria.

Aldolase B is another isoform of the aldolase enzyme family. Unlike aldolase A, aldolase B plays a crucial role in fructose metabolism. It catalyzes the cleavage of fructose-1-phosphate into glyceraldehyde and dihydroxyacetone phosphate. Deficiency of aldolase B is associated with hereditary fructose intolerance, a condition characterized by the inability to metabolize fructose. 

Sucrase, also known as sucrase-isomaltase, is an enzyme involved in the digestion of sucrose (table sugar) into glucose and fructose. It is primarily found in the brush border of the small intestine. Deficiency of sucrase results in a condition known as congenital sucrase-isomaltase deficiency (CSID), which leads to gastrointestinal symptoms upon ingestion of sucrose-containing foods.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes disease following traumatic inoculation into the skin?
questions.solution:
Sporothrix schenckii causes an infection followed by traumatic inoculation into the skin.

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is usually followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes. 

It is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It is in the yeast phase in tissues and in cultures at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase in nature and cultures at 25°C. When it is cultured, the colonies are blackish-brown and fuzzy. The organism produces branching, septate hyphae, and microconidia clustered at the ends of conidiophores. It exists as cigar-shaped yeast cells. Stains used for identifying yeast forms: 

  • Gomori methenamine silver-cell wall appears black
  • Periodic acid-Schiff stain - cell wall appears red 
  • Fluorescent antibody staining

The image given below shows, (A)- (i) culture at 37°C (ii) culture at 25°C. (B) fungi with clustered microconidia with conidiophore.  (C) Magnified image showing branching and septate hyphae.

Direct microscopic examination of necrotic material in KOH mount or histopathological examination of tissue sections stained by methenamine silver stain shows the asteroid body. Asteroid body is a rounded or oval, basophilic, yeast-like body 3-5 μmin diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell.

Clinical features: The initial infection develops as a nodule, which may break down to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. Untreated, the disease progresses and new nodules develop along the lymphatics leading to a chain of nodules. Less commonly it may also cause systemic infection following inhalation, which causes local pulmonary disease or may lead to widely disseminated lesions in joints, meninges, and skin.

Treatment: Itraconazole is the drug of choice for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. 

Other treatment options for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis:

  • Terbinafine
  • SSKI- Saturated solution of potassium iodide
  • Fluconazole
  • Local hyperthermia

Amphotericin B can be used for disseminated infections.
